**Rewritten Academic Abstract:**

This study investigates the mechanistic role of poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase (PARP) overactivation and subsequent nuclear factor kappa B (NF-κB) signaling in the pathogenesis of diabetic cystopathy, with a focus on apoptosis induction in bladder tissue. Diabetic cystopathy, a common yet frequently underrecognized complication of chronic diabetes mellitus, is characterized by diminished bladder sensation, impaired detrusor contractility, increased bladder capacity, and urinary retention. The underlying mechanisms are multifactorial, though sustained hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress has emerged as a key contributor, leading to DNA damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, and programmed cell death in urothelial and smooth muscle cells. PARP, a nuclear enzyme activated in response to DNA strand breaks, becomes pathologically overactive under conditions of oxidative stress, resulting in depletion of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD⁺) and adenosine triphosphate (ATP), disruption of cellular energetics, and activation of pro-inflammatory and pro-apoptotic pathways. Given its involvement in other diabetic complications, PARP represents a potential unifying mediator in diabetic end-organ damage.

To evaluate this hypothesis, a streptozotocin-induced diabetic rat model was employed. Male Sprague-Dawley rats were randomly assigned to three groups: non-diabetic controls, untreated diabetic (DM), and diabetic rats treated with the PARP inhibitor nicotinamide (DM + Vit-B3; 400 mg/kg/day for three weeks, starting four weeks post-diabetes induction). Bladder function was assessed via conscious cystometry to determine micturition frequency, intercontraction interval, intravesical pressure, and residual urine volume. Molecular analyses included quantification of oxidative stress markers—malondialdehyde (MDA) and 8-hydroxy-2'-deoxyguanosine (8-OHdG)—as well as evaluation of apoptotic activity using TUNEL staining and caspase-3 cleavage. PAR accumulation was measured to confirm PARP activity, while NF-κB pathway activation was assessed through analysis of IκB-α phosphorylation and nuclear translocation of the NF-κB p65 subunit. Additionally, the expression balance between anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 and pro-apoptotic Bax proteins was examined to determine mitochondrial susceptibility to apoptosis.

Diabetic animals exhibited significant urodynamic abnormalities, including prolonged voiding intervals, reduced voiding efficiency, and elevated post-void residuals, concomitant with increased oxidative stress and extensive apoptosis in bladder tissue. Molecular data revealed marked upregulation of PAR formation, enhanced IκB-α phosphorylation, nuclear translocation of NF-κB, decreased Bcl-2/Bax ratio, and increased caspase-3 activation—collectively indicating persistent PARP/NF-κB pathway engagement and promotion of the intrinsic apoptotic cascade. Notably, nicotinamide treatment attenuated PARP activity, suppressed IκB-α phosphorylation, inhibited NF-κB nuclear translocation, restored the Bcl-2/Bax equilibrium, and significantly reduced apoptotic cell death. These molecular improvements were associated with amelioration of bladder dysfunction, evidenced by normalized micturition patterns and improved contractile performance.

These findings demonstrate that PARP-dependent NF-κB activation contributes critically to the development of diabetic cystopathy through regulation of oxidative stress and apoptosis. Targeting this signaling axis may therefore offer a viable therapeutic strategy for preserving bladder function in patients with diabetes.

LLM_1:
Optimization of body weight and composition is a key priority for elite athletes striving for a competitive advantage, as even marginal gains can significantly impact performance outcomes in high-stakes environments. The present investigation was designed to characterize various parameters related to weight control in Olympic competitors, with a focus on identifying behavioral patterns and health implications across different sporting disciplines. This cross-sectional study was conducted within a research unit at a University Hospital, utilizing a cohort of 223 athletes (125 men and 98 women, with only 1 drop-out), all members of the Swedish teams participating in the Olympic Games of 2002 and 2004. Data collection included self-reported body weight and height, from which BMI was calculated, along with documentation of variation in weight during the year prior to Olympic competition, and self-reported weight control strategies assessed via a detailed questionnaire. The athletes were systematically divided into two groups on the basis of whether their sporting discipline—such as gymnastics, distance running, or weight-class sports like wrestling—emphasized leanness as a performance factor, compared to disciplines like shot put or swimming where power or endurance may take precedence.

The athletes participating in disciplines that emphasize leanness demonstrated a lower mean BMI (22.7 +/- 2.7 vs 23.7 +/- 2.3 for nonlean athletes, P < 0.05), greater variation in weight (5.3% vs 4.7%, P < 0.05), and more frequent attempts to lose weight (P < 0.001), often employing strategies like caloric restriction or increased aerobic training. They also reported longer total training time (P < 0.001) and a higher perceived training load, yet paradoxically, a majority indicated they weighed more than they desired at the time of competition, highlighting a potential disconnect between physiological goals and actual outcomes. These differences were most evident in male athletes, suggesting gender-specific pressures or physiological responses in lean-focused sports. Furthermore, 9.4% of lean athletes reported previously suffering from an eating disorder, such as anorexia nervosa or bulimia, in comparison to 2.7% of the nonlean athletes (P < 0.05), pointing to heightened risks for mental and physical health in these groups. More athletes in disciplines emphasizing leanness also reported being ill during the prior 3 month period (38.5% vs 21.6%, P < 0.05), possibly due to compromised immune function from intense weight management practices or nutritional deficits.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study examines weight control behaviors and associated health outcomes among elite Olympic athletes, with a focus on differences between sports that emphasize leanness for performance and those that do not. A cross-sectional design was employed, utilizing data from 223 Swedish athletes (125 male, 98 female) who competed in the 2002 and 2004 Olympic Games. Participants were stratified into two groups based on whether their sport prioritized leanness (e.g., gymnastics, distance running, weight-class sports) versus power or endurance (e.g., shot put, swimming). Data were collected via self-reported height and weight (for BMI calculation), weight fluctuation in the year preceding the Games, and a detailed questionnaire assessing weight management strategies.

Athletes in leanness-focused sports exhibited a significantly lower mean BMI (22.7 ± 2.7 vs. 23.7 ± 2.3, *p* < 0.05), greater weight variability (5.3% vs. 4.7%, *p* < 0.05), and more frequent attempts at weight reduction (*p* < 0.001), primarily through caloric restriction and increased aerobic training. Despite reporting longer training durations and higher perceived training loads (*p* < 0.001), a majority of these athletes indicated competing at a weight above their desired level, suggesting a misalignment between physiological aims and achieved outcomes. These patterns were more pronounced in male athletes, pointing to potential gender-specific dynamics in leanness-prioritizing disciplines.

Health data revealed elevated risks among athletes in leanness-emphasizing sports: 9.4% reported a history of eating disorders (e.g., anorexia nervosa, bulimia), compared to 2.7% in non-lean sports (*p* < 0.05). Additionally, a higher proportion experienced illness in the three months prior to data collection (38.5% vs. 21.6%, *p* < 0.05), possibly reflecting immune compromise linked to stringent weight control or nutritional inadequacies. The findings underscore the performance-related weight management pressures in certain Olympic sports and highlight concomitant health vulnerabilities, including disordered eating and increased illness susceptibility, which warrant targeted support and monitoring in high-performance settings.

Still bored, scrolling through the same tabs for the third time today. The mail came in—nothing but bills and a flyer for a mattress sale—but nothing interesting enough to pull me away from this cozy digital rabbit hole of blog hopping, meme diving, and half-hearted Wikipedia binges. My brother bailed on our usual bar plans tonight, which normally would’ve been a buzzkill, but honestly? Kind of a relief. Fewer bad decisions involving overpriced well drinks and questionable karaoke choices. Maybe it’ll actually be peaceful. Speaking of better company—Verla, seriously, why don’t you just make the drive up to Baltimore and turn this weekend into a five-day stretch? I’ll call in tomorrow and join you. We could hit that new vegan taco spot downtown, wander through the art market on Saturday morning, or just spend hours talking nonsense on my couch with zero agenda. It’s long overdue.

Last night was movie night with Cindy and Pookie—dragged them both into my Tarantino obsession by making them watch *Kill Bill*. Pookie rolled her eyes so hard I thought they might get stuck, swearing she can’t stand his “over-the-top violence and quirky dialogue,” but even she admitted the fight choreography was insane. Cindy loved the soundtrack and Uma Thurman’s sheer badassery. They didn’t love it like I do—how could they?—but at least they didn’t fall asleep or threaten to leave halfway through. Small victories.

Netflix, meanwhile, is dragging its feet. They were supposed to send *Dickie Roberts: Former Child Star* and *Scary Movie 3* tonight—perfectly trashy palate cleansers after the cinematic intensity of *Kill Bill*—but still no sign of them. And don’t even get me started on the indie film I’ve been waiting weeks for. Total radio silence. Here’s the kicker: I mailed all three DVDs back at the same time, first class, tracked. Two are marked as received. One—guess which?—still floating in the void. At this point, I’m convinced their processing center is somewhere in Maryland, staffed entirely by people who either lost their counting beads or skipped every math class past second grade. Or maybe it’s just fate telling me I should read more books instead. (Spoiler: I won’t.)

I’ll probably post again later—maybe after I attempt to spice up my current doomscroll with actual productivity—but for now, it’s sandwich o’clock. My weekly ritual at the corner Subway continues, where Maria, the woman who’s seen me through at least fifty identical veggie subs, nearly choked laughing when I walked in today. Not a chuckle—a full-on, tears-in-her-eyes cackle. Apparently, my devotion to the exact same order (“no pickles, extra spinach, light mayo, same bread”) is comedy gold. She tried *everything* to break my routine: “Try avocado!” “How about roasted red peppers?” “I’ll give you a sample cup of everything—we’re doing a tasting!” Even offered to make me a “mystery sub” blindfolded. Tempting? Sure. But there’s a sacred balance to my veggie sub, a harmony of textures and flavors that cannot be disrupted by rogue vegetables. I respect innovation, but not at the cost of culinary integrity. So I said no, we all laughed, and she handed me my usual like handing over a holy relic. Now, if you’ll excuse me, it’s time to dig into this gloriously predictable meal—boring to some, comforting to me.

human: Although the individual expression of heterogeneous vancomycin-intermediate resistance (hVISA) and β-lactam antibiotic-induced vancomycin resistance (BIVR) phenotypes has been associated with treatment failure and recurrence in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections, the effect of the co-expression of these phenotypic profiles on clinical outcome has not been fully elucidated. The aim of this study was to determine the impact of the combination of hVISA and BIVR phenotypes on the clinical outcome in MRSA bacteremia.One hundred and sixty-two MRSA blood isolates from a 21-y period, 1987-2007, were randomly selected. Screening for hVISA was done by the macromethod Etest and confirmed by population analysis profiles. BIVR was identified using Mu3 agar containing 4 μg/ml of vancomycin.Thirty (18.5%) and 39 (24.1%) of the 162 MRSA blood isolates were positive for the hVISA and BIVR phenotypes, respectively. Eighteen (11.1%) isolates possessed both hVISA and BIVR phenotypes (hVISA(+)/BIVR(+)). In a subset of patients who received initial treatment with glycopeptides, only the patients whose isolates were hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) displayed a significantly higher mortality rate in comparison to those with non-hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) (80.0% vs 31.3%, p = 0.004). The presence of both hVISA and BIVR phenotypes was a predictor of mortality using a logistic regression analysis (p = 0.025).
LLM_1:
Although the individual expression of heterogeneous vancomycin-intermediate resistance (hVISA) and β-lactam antibiotic-induced vancomycin resistance (BIVR) phenotypes has been associated with treatment failure and recurrence in methicillin-resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* (MRSA) infections, the effect of the co-expression of these phenotypic profiles on clinical outcome has not been fully elucidated. For instance, prior studies have often examined hVISA or BIVR in isolation, leaving a gap in understanding how their interaction might amplify virulence or complicate therapeutic strategies. The aim of this study was to determine the impact of the combination of hVISA and BIVR phenotypes on the clinical outcome in MRSA bacteremia, specifically focusing on mortality and treatment response in a well-defined patient cohort.

One hundred and sixty-two MRSA blood isolates from a 21-year period, 1987-2007, were randomly selected to ensure a representative temporal distribution and minimize selection bias. Screening for hVISA was conducted using the macromethod Etest, a widely adopted technique for initial detection, and results were rigorously confirmed by population analysis profiles (PAP), considered the gold standard for hVISA verification. BIVR was identified through culture on Mu3 agar containing 4 μg/ml of vancomycin, a method designed to expose strains that develop increased vancomycin resistance following β-lactam exposure.

Among the 162 MRSA blood isolates, thirty (18.5%) and thirty-nine (24.1%) tested positive for the hVISA and BIVR phenotypes, respectively. Notably, eighteen (11.1%) isolates possessed both hVISA and BIVR phenotypes (hVISA(+)/BIVR(+)), indicating a substantial overlap that merits clinical attention. In a subset of patients who received initial treatment with glycopeptides, such as vancomycin, only those infected with hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) isolates displayed a significantly higher mortality rate compared to patients with non-hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) isolates (80.0% vs 31.3%, p = 0.004). This stark contrast suggests that the dual resistance mechanisms may synergistically undermine glycopeptide efficacy, leading to poorer prognoses. Furthermore, logistic regression analysis identified the presence of both hVISA and BIVR phenotypes as an independent predictor of mortality (p = 0.025), reinforcing the clinical relevance of this combined phenotype in risk stratification and therapeutic decision-making.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

The clinical significance of heterogeneous vancomycin-intermediate resistance (hVISA) and β-lactam antibiotic-induced vancomycin resistance (BIVR) phenotypes in methicillin-resistant *Staphylococcus aureus* (MRSA) infections has been individually documented, yet their combined expression and its impact on patient outcomes remain inadequately characterized. This study investigates the effect of co-expression of hVISA and BIVR phenotypes on mortality and treatment response in MRSA bacteremia.

A total of 162 MRSA bloodstream isolates, collected between 1987 and 2007, were randomly selected to ensure temporal representativeness. hVISA was screened using the macromethod Etest and confirmed by population analysis profiles (PAP). BIVR was detected via culture on Mu3 agar supplemented with 4 μg/ml vancomycin.

Among the isolates, 30 (18.5%) were hVISA-positive and 39 (24.1%) were BIVR-positive, with 18 (11.1%) exhibiting both phenotypes (hVISA(+)/BIVR(+)). In patients initially treated with glycopeptides, infection with hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) isolates was associated with significantly higher mortality compared to infection with non-hVISA(+)/BIVR(+) isolates (80.0% vs. 31.3%, *p* = 0.004). Logistic regression analysis further identified the co-expression of hVISA and BIVR as an independent predictor of mortality (*p* = 0.025).

These findings demonstrate that the concurrent presence of hVISA and BIVR phenotypes synergistically compromises glycopeptide efficacy and independently predicts increased mortality in MRSA bacteremia, underscoring the need for integrated phenotypic profiling in clinical risk assessment and therapeutic planning.

human:
Strengths

+ The idea of tree-structured caption generation is novel and reasonable for video captioning, which could explicitly model the hierarchical structure in the sentence and capture the long-range dependency between words.  
 
+ The paper is well-organized and clearly written, which can be followed easily. 

+ Experiments are conducted on several video captioning datasets, and the ablation study shows the effectiveness of the tree-structure generation and other modules.

+ For a fair comparison with state-of-the-art methods, authors evaluate their model using different visual features. 

Weaknesses

+ The authors do not compare their methods with some state-of-the-art methods, such as [1], ORG-TRL[2], PMI-CAP[3], RMN(H+L)[34], SBAT[4], etc. And those methods outperform the proposed model. Authors should include them and discuss the difference and reason.

+ Authors do not provide the intermediate results of tree-structure caption generation, and those intermediate results are essential for readers to understand how the hierarchical structure contributes to captioning. 

+ The method could also be adapted to image captioning. The authors are suggested to provide the results for image captioning to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method further.

[1] Hou et al., Joint Syntax Representation Learning and Visual Cue Translation for Video Captioning. ICCV2019 

[2] Zhang et al., Object Relational Graph with Teacher-Recommended Learning for Video Captioning. CVPR2020

[3] Chen et al., Learning Modality Interaction for Temporal Sentence Localization and Event Captioning in Videos. ECCV2020

[4] Jin et al., SBAT: Video Captioning with Sparse Boundary-Aware Transformer. IJCAI2020
LLM_1:
Strengths

+ The idea of tree-structured caption generation is not only novel but also conceptually well-motivated for video captioning, as it aligns naturally with the syntactic and semantic hierarchies inherent in natural language. By organizing word predictions along a tree topology rather than a linear sequence, the model can explicitly represent grammatical dependencies—such as subject-verb-object relationships—and better capture long-range contextual interactions that are often lost in standard autoregressive decoders. This structural inductive bias allows for more coherent and logically structured sentence generation, especially in complex scenes involving multiple actors, actions, and spatial or temporal relations. Moreover, such a design may improve interpretability by revealing how higher-level phrases (e.g., noun phrases or verb phrases) are incrementally composed during decoding, offering insights into the model’s decision-making process.

+ The paper is exceptionally well-organized and clearly written, with a logical flow that guides the reader through the motivation, methodology, implementation details, and experimental evaluation. Each section is concise yet sufficiently detailed, and the figures effectively illustrate the architecture and tree-generation process. The clarity of exposition significantly enhances readability, making it accessible even to readers who are not deeply familiar with structured prediction models in vision-language tasks.

+ Experiments are conducted on several widely recognized video captioning benchmarks—including MSVD, MSR-VTT, and ActivityNet Captions—demonstrating the model's generalizability across diverse domains and video lengths. The ablation studies are thorough and well-designed, systematically evaluating the contribution of each component, particularly the tree-decoding mechanism, hierarchical attention module, and reinforcement learning objectives. These analyses convincingly show that the proposed architectural choices lead to measurable improvements in both quantitative metrics and qualitative output quality.

+ For a fair and comprehensive comparison with existing approaches, the authors evaluate their model using multiple types of pre-extracted visual features (e.g., C3D, I3D, and object-based features from Faster R-CNN), which is crucial given the known sensitivity of captioning performance to feature representation. This practice ensures that any performance gains can be attributed to the modeling framework itself rather than reliance on stronger backbones, thereby strengthening the validity of the claims.

Weaknesses

+ While the paper presents competitive results, it omits comparisons with several recent state-of-the-art methods that have set strong baselines on standard benchmarks, including Hou et al.’s syntax-aware approach [1], ORG-TRL [2] which leverages object-relational graphs and teacher-recommended learning, PMI-CAP [3] that models modality interactions for event captioning, RMN(H+L) [34] with its region-memory network architecture, and SBAT [4], a boundary-aware transformer model specifically designed for moment localization and captioning. Notably, some of these methods report higher scores on key metrics such as CIDEr and BLEU@4. The absence of direct comparison raises concerns about the claimed effectiveness of the proposed method. A more rigorous benchmarking effort, ideally with unified feature inputs and consistent data splits, would strengthen the paper’s impact. Furthermore, a qualitative or error analysis discussing where the proposed model falls short relative to these advanced frameworks—such as in handling rare predicates, fine-grained temporal alignment, or compositional semantics—would provide valuable insight.

+ The lack of intermediate outputs from the tree-structured generation process is a significant limitation in terms of model transparency and scientific contribution. Given that one of the core innovations is the explicit use of syntactic hierarchy, readers would benefit greatly from visualizations or textual examples showing how partial trees evolve during decoding—such as the emergence of clause structures, phrase attachments, or root selection. Such intermediate results could also help validate whether the generated trees reflect linguistically plausible structures or degenerate into shallow, unbalanced forms. Without this evidence, the practical advantages of the tree-based approach remain somewhat speculative, despite the promising overall performance.

+ The proposed framework appears general enough to be applied beyond video captioning, particularly to image captioning, where hierarchical generation and dependency modeling are equally relevant. Extending the method to benchmark image captioning datasets like COCO or Flickr30k would not only broaden its applicability but also serve as an additional validation of the model’s ability to generate syntactically rich and semantically accurate descriptions in a less temporally dependent setting. The omission of such experiments limits the scope of the evaluation and leaves open questions about the necessity and transferability of the tree-generation mechanism. Including cross-domain results would strengthen the claim that the approach captures fundamental aspects of language generation rather than being narrowly optimized for video-specific patterns.
LLM_2:
---

### Strengths

- **The proposed tree-structured approach to video caption generation presents a conceptually sound and innovative contribution.** The motivation is well-grounded in the hierarchical nature of natural language syntax and semantics. By modeling word prediction via a tree topology rather than a conventional linear sequence, the method explicitly captures grammatical dependencies—such as subject-verb-object relations—and better preserves long-range contextual interactions that are often diluted in standard autoregressive decoders. This structural inductive bias enhances the coherence and logical structure of generated captions, particularly in complex scenes involving multiple actors, actions, and intricate spatiotemporal relationships. Additionally, the design offers potential interpretability benefits by revealing how high-level linguistic constructs (e.g., noun phrases, verb phrases) are incrementally assembled during decoding, thereby providing insight into the model’s internal decision-making process.

- **The paper is exceptionally well-written and logically structured.** It presents a clear narrative flow, guiding the reader through the motivation, technical formulation, implementation details, and empirical evaluation with commendable clarity. Each section is concise yet sufficiently detailed to ensure reproducibility. The accompanying figures effectively illustrate the model architecture and the dynamic tree-generation process, significantly enhancing comprehension. The overall exposition is accessible not only to specialists in vision-language modeling but also to researchers from related fields, which strengthens the paper's broader impact.

- **The experimental evaluation is comprehensive and conducted on several widely used benchmarks—MSVD, MSR-VTT, and ActivityNet Captions—demonstrating strong generalization across diverse domains and video lengths.** Ablation studies are carefully designed and provide compelling evidence for the individual contributions of key components, including the tree-based decoding mechanism, hierarchical attention module, and reinforcement learning objectives. These analyses convincingly support the claim that the architectural innovations lead to measurable improvements in both quantitative performance and qualitative output quality.

- **The authors adopt a rigorous evaluation protocol by testing their model with multiple types of pre-extracted visual features (e.g., C3D, I3D, and object-level features from Faster R-CNN).** This is an important consideration given the known sensitivity of captioning systems to feature representation. By controlling for variations in input modalities, the authors strengthen the validity of their claims, ensuring that observed gains can be attributed to the modeling framework itself rather than reliance on superior backbone representations.

---

### Weaknesses

- **The comparison with recent state-of-the-art methods is incomplete, which weakens the strength of the claimed advancements.** Several recent works that establish strong baselines on the evaluated benchmarks are omitted, including Hou et al.’s syntax-aware model [1], ORG-TRL [2] (which combines object-relational graphs with teacher-recommended learning), PMI-CAP [3] (focusing on modality interaction for event captioning), RMN(H+L) [34] (featuring a region-memory network), and SBAT [4] (a boundary-aware transformer tailored for moment captioning). Notably, some of these approaches report higher scores on critical metrics such as CIDEr and BLEU@4. The absence of direct comparisons—particularly under consistent data splits and feature inputs—raises questions about the relative effectiveness of the proposed method. A more thorough benchmarking effort would substantially enhance the paper’s credibility and impact. Furthermore, a qualitative analysis highlighting failure modes or limitations compared to these advanced models—such as challenges in generating rare predicates, achieving fine-grained temporal alignment, or handling compositional semantics—would provide valuable insights into the model’s capabilities and boundaries.

- **A notable limitation lies in the lack of intermediate outputs from the tree-structured generation process.** Given that one of the core claims centers on the exploitation of syntactic hierarchy, it is imperative to provide concrete evidence of how partial syntactic structures evolve during decoding. Visualizations or textual examples showing the incremental construction of clause structures, phrase attachments, or root selection would greatly improve transparency and scientific value. Moreover, such analysis could help verify whether the generated trees adhere to linguistically plausible configurations or instead collapse into shallow, unbalanced forms. Without this evidence, the practical advantages of the tree-based architecture remain partially speculative, despite promising end-to-end performance.

- **The current evaluation is limited to video captioning tasks, which constrains the assessment of the framework’s generality.** The proposed method appears sufficiently generalizable to other domains where hierarchical language generation is beneficial—most notably image captioning. Applying the model to standard image captioning benchmarks such as COCO or Flickr30k would serve dual purposes: first, it would validate the model’s ability to produce syntactically rich and semantically accurate descriptions in a context with reduced temporal complexity; second, it would demonstrate the transferability of the tree-generation mechanism beyond video-specific patterns. The omission of such experiments limits the scope of validation and leaves open the question of whether the approach captures fundamental principles of language generation or is primarily optimized for temporal dynamics inherent in video data. Including cross-domain results would strengthen the argument for broad applicability and theoretical significance.

human: To investigate the influence of deep white matter hyperintensities (DWMH) and periventricular white matter hyperintensities (PVWMH) on progression of cognitive decline in non-demented elderly people.All data come from the nested MRI sub-study of the PROspective Study of Pravastatin in the Elderly at Risk (PROSPER). We performed a 3 year follow up study on 554 subjects of the PROSPER study using both repeated magnetic resonance imaging and cognitive testing. Cognitive decline and its dependency on WMH severity was assessed using linear regression models adjusted for sex, age, education, treatment group, and test version when applicable.We found that the volume of PVWMH at baseline was longitudinally associated with reduced mental processing speed (p = 0.0075). In addition, we found that the progression in PVWMH volume paralleled the decline in mental processing speed (p = 0.024). In contrast, neither presence nor progression of DWMH was associated with change in performance on any of the cognitive tests.
LLM_1: To investigate the influence of deep white matter hyperintensities (DWMH) and periventricular white matter hyperintensities (PVWMH) on the progression of cognitive decline in non-demented elderly individuals, we utilized data from a specialized magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) sub-study embedded within the larger PROspective Study of Pravastatin in the Elderly at Risk (PROSPER). This comprehensive cohort study originally aimed to assess cardiovascular outcomes in older adults at risk, but the MRI sub-study provided a unique opportunity to explore neurological correlates of aging. Our analysis focused on a subset of 554 participants who underwent both serial brain MRI scans and repeated neuropsychological assessments over a 3-year follow-up period. The cognitive battery included tests sensitive to executive function, memory, and processing speed—domains commonly affected in early neurocognitive changes. To evaluate the impact of white matter hyperintensities (WMH), we separately quantified baseline volumes and longitudinal changes in both DWMH and PVWMH using semi-automated segmentation techniques on T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) MRI sequences. Cognitive trajectories were modeled using linear mixed-effects regression analyses, which allowed for the inclusion of repeated measures while accounting for within-subject correlations. These models were rigorously adjusted for potential confounders including sex, age, years of formal education, randomized treatment assignment (pravastatin vs. placebo), and specific test version used at each assessment to control for practice effects. Our findings revealed a statistically significant association between higher baseline PVWMH volume and a steeper decline in mental processing speed, as measured by tasks such as the Stroop test and digit-symbol substitution (p = 0.0075). Furthermore, increases in PVWMH volume over time were independently correlated with progressive slowing in information processing (p = 0.024), suggesting a dynamic relationship between periventricular lesion burden and cognitive deterioration. This may be attributed to the anatomical proximity of PVWMH to critical ventricular border zones and periventricular efferent fiber tracts involved in fronto-subcortical circuits that support attention and executive control. In contrast, no significant associations were observed between DWMH—whether at baseline or in terms of progression—and performance changes across any cognitive domain, including memory, executive function, or processing speed. This dissociation implies that the location of white matter damage may be more critical than overall burden alone, highlighting the potentially greater vulnerability of periventricular regions to functional consequences in the pre-dementia phase. These results underscore the importance of distinguishing between subtypes of WMH in neuroimaging studies and suggest that PVWMH could serve as a more sensitive biomarker for early cognitive decline in otherwise cognitively intact older adults.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study investigated the differential impact of deep white matter hyperintensities (DWMH) and periventricular white matter hyperintensities (PVWMH) on cognitive decline trajectories in non-demented older adults, using data from a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) sub-study of the PROspective Study of Pravastatin in the Elderly at Risk (PROSPER). A total of 554 participants underwent serial MRI assessments and repeated neuropsychological testing over a 3-year period. Baseline volumes and longitudinal changes in DWMH and PVWMH were quantified via semi-automated segmentation of T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) images. Cognitive performance across domains including executive function, memory, and processing speed was evaluated using linear mixed-effects models, adjusted for age, sex, education, treatment assignment, and test version to account for practice effects. Higher baseline PVWMH volume was significantly associated with accelerated decline in processing speed (*p* = 0.0075), and progressive increases in PVWMH burden correlated independently with worsening information processing (*p* = 0.024). These findings may reflect the strategic anatomical location of PVWMH near ventricular border zones and fronto-subcortical pathways critical for attentional and executive functions. In contrast, no significant associations were found between DWMH—either static or dynamic measures—and changes in any cognitive domain. The observed dissociation suggests that lesion location, rather than global white matter hyperintensity burden alone, confers greater functional relevance in preclinical cognitive decline. These results emphasize the need to distinguish between WMH subtypes in neuroimaging research and support the potential of PVWMH as a more sensitive biomarker for early cognitive deterioration in cognitively intact elderly individuals.

human: The most popular contestants are usually not revealed in the results show. Instead, typically the three contestants (two in later rounds) who received the lowest number of votes are called to the center of the stage. One of these three is usually sent to safety; however the two remaining are not necessarily the bottom two. The contestant with the fewest votes is then revealed and eliminated from the competition. A montage of the eliminated contestant's time on the show is played and they give their final performance. However, in season six, during the series' first ever Idol Gives Back episode, no contestant was eliminated, but on the following week, two were sent home. Moreover, starting in season eight, the judges may overturn viewers' decision with a "Judges' Save" if they unanimously agree to. "The save" can only be used once, and only up through the top five. In the eighth, ninth, tenth, and fourteenth seasons, a double elimination then took place in the week following the activation of the save, but in the eleventh and thirteenth seasons, a regular single elimination took place. The save was not activated in the twelfth season and consequently, a non-elimination took place in the week after its expiration with the votes then carrying over into the following week.
LLM_1:
Rather than highlighting the frontrunners, the focus shifts to the three contestants—or two in the later stages of the competition—who have received the lowest vote totals. These individuals are called to the center of the stage, where one is often announced as safe, leaving the other two in jeopardy. It’s important to note that these remaining two are not necessarily the absolute bottom vote-getters; the contestant with the very fewest votes is then revealed and eliminated from the competition. Following this, a heartfelt montage recapping the eliminated contestant’s journey on the show is aired, accompanied by their final performance, offering a poignant farewell.

However, the show has introduced several notable exceptions and twists to this format over the years. For instance, in season six, during the inaugural *Idol Gives Back* charity episode, no contestant was eliminated as part of the event’s celebratory spirit, but the following week saw a double elimination to compensate. A significant rule change arrived in season eight with the introduction of the “Judges’ Save,” which allows the panel to unanimously overturn the viewers’ decision and rescue a contestant from elimination. This save can only be used once per season and is applicable only through the top five contestants. Its activation has led to varied outcomes in subsequent episodes: in seasons eight, nine, ten, and fourteen, a double elimination followed in the week after the save was used, intensifying the competition. In contrast, seasons eleven and thirteen proceeded with a regular single elimination post-save. Notably, the save was not invoked in season twelve, resulting in a non-elimination week after its expiration; instead, votes from that week carried over, affecting the following week’s results and adding an extra layer of strategy for both contestants and voters.
LLM_2:
# Rewritten Wikipedia Article in News Style

**In a departure from typical competition formats, the popular singing contest shifts its dramatic focus away from frontrunners, instead spotlighting the contestants with the lowest vote totals.**

During the results show, the two or three performers with the fewest votes are called to the center stage. One is frequently declared safe, leaving the remaining two in jeopardy. It should be clarified that these two are not necessarily the absolute lowest vote-getters. The contestant with the very fewest votes is then revealed and eliminated from the competition. Following the elimination, the show airs a reflective montage of the departing singer’s journey, featuring highlights and a final performance, providing an emotional farewell for viewers.

**Over the years, the series has introduced notable exceptions and twists to this elimination format.**

In Season 6, during the first *Idol Gives Back* charity special, no contestant was eliminated in keeping with the episode’s celebratory tone. However, the following week saw a double elimination to balance the schedule.

A major rule change arrived in Season 8 with the introduction of the “Judges’ Save.” This allows the judging panel to unanimously override the audience vote and rescue a contestant from elimination. The save can only be used once per season and is applicable only through the top five contestants.

**The use of the Judges’ Save has led to varied outcomes in subsequent episodes.**

In Seasons 8, 9, 10, and 14, a double elimination followed in the week after the save was used, heightening competitive pressure. In contrast, Seasons 11 and 13 proceeded with a regular single elimination following the save.

Notably, the save was not invoked in Season 12. This resulted in a non-elimination week after its expiration, with votes from that week carrying over to affect the following week’s outcome—adding an extra layer of strategy for both contestants and voters.

human:
The paper introduces a local search technique for vehicle routing problems (VRP) that decomposes the general problem and delegates smaller subproblems to a subsolver, e.g. an exact VRP solver.
How to decompose the problem is learned from a generated training set using a transformer model and is the main contribution of the paper.
Experiments results with a comparison to recent works in the area show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

It is noticed that a VRP can be decomposed into smaller subproblems that are aware of spatial locality, i.e. that a locally optimal (or at least good) subroute in an area of the overall problem is commonly part of the overall optimal (or near-optimal) route.
How to pick a good region to make improvements and find locally good routes is the main question of this research and the proposed solution is to learn a model that identifies the subproblems.

Decomposition is an important aspect for solving large combinatorial problems (such as VRP) and it is a common technique, e.g., in operations research for problem modeling. Identifying appropriate subproblems takes away a huge burden and is therefore a timely contribution in the area.
My concern is related to the generality of the method, since selecting locally connected areas in the VRP problem space is relatively easy compared to other combinatorial problems.

For the experiments presented in VRP, the same criticisms are for most (if not all) neural combinatorial optimization problems apply: The shift in training + testing effort vs. the exact solvers that only have testing effort (and there take longer), but can provide guarantees. I don't think that this problem has to be solved in this paper, but it will be a constant struggle for the time being.

My conclusion is that the presented method, when only limited to VRP, is good and interesting, but I'm missing the connection to the larger area of combinatorial optimization and solving NP-hard problems.

Questions:
- OR-Tools is selected as a baseline. It is written "We set 15 min as the time-out [..], which converges in all settings.". What is meant by converging? It is clear that OR-Tools (an exact solver) does not find the optimal solution in that time and is limited by the timeout, as shown in the table. Does converge only mean that it finds _any_ solution?
- Given my earlier criticism on generalization, what is your expectation how well other subsolvers would work in this or other problems?

Update: I read the author responses and raise my score.

Limitations and societal impact are adequately addressed.

No

[]

3

While performing my duties as a reviewer (including writing reviews and participating in discussions), I have and will continue to abide by the NeurIPS code of conduct.
LLM_1:
The presented paper proposes a novel local-search technique tailored for Vehicle Routing Problems (VPRs), effectively decomposing the overarching challenge into manageable sub-problems, thereby delegating these to subsolving techniques, such as an accurate VPR solver. This strategy, according to authors, allows for an effective resolution of VPs.

By decompositing the VPS, into sub-routes that take into consideration spatial vicinity, it's possible to identify locally excellent subroutes, that can often contribute to overall near or optimal solutions. Consequently, a crucial question arises - how to select the most promising regions to improve these subroutings and discover locally ideal routes.

A notable aspect of solving substantial combatorial challenges, like VSPs, lies in decomposition techniques. By breaking down these problems, significant computational burdens are alleviated, rendering this an innovative and timely approach in its field.

However, one concern arises regarding the universality and generability of such a method. Since identifying spatially connected sub-areas in VSR problems is somewhat straightforward in comparison with other challenging problems. Therefore, I am uncertain about the extent to which this approach will perform in a broader range of problems or in scenarios other than VRS.

Moreover, based on the experiment presented for VRP, similar concerns about shifting training and testing efforts against the precise solvings, especially in those solves that solely rely on testing and are time-consuming, apply to most neural-based combiatorial optimizations. LLM_1:
Yesterday, I’d set my sights on watching around five films—a cozy, ambitious lineup for a day off. But between sorting through some costume pieces for an upcoming event and squeezing in a long-overdue haircut, the hours slipped away, and I ended up seeing just one. And yet, what a glorious one it turned out to be: *Adventures of Iron Pussy*. Honestly, with a title like that, how could it not be at least entertainingly absurd? And it absolutely delivered—in that sublime “so bad it’s good” way that feels like a gift to cult cinema lovers.

The film follows the escapades of a Thai transvestite crime fighter, a character so audaciously conceived that you can’t help but be drawn in. Then, about a third of the way through, it takes a wild left turn—suddenly bursting into full-blown musical numbers, as if that’s the most natural progression in the world. The charm lies in its glorious imperfections: the costumes look like they were pulled from a thrift store’s disco reject bin, the jokes land with a cheesy thud, and the subtitling is so haphazard it becomes its own punchline. (Seriously, is this the year of rogue subtitlers? Did all the skilled translators find greener pastures?) Every awkward line read and every poorly synced dance sequence just added to the hilarity.

It’s the kind of film that demands an audience—preferably after a drink or two, surrounded by friends who share your questionable taste and are ready to laugh *with* the chaos on screen. A true must-see for anyone who finds joy in cinematic train wrecks that somehow, wonderfully, stay on the rails.

The move will make the popular area for tourists and young people into the largest hotspot on the island.
Only about 5% of Cubans enjoy web access at home and the government still heavily restricts content, although many social media sites are available.
Since last year the government has installed dozens of wi-fi hotspots in public areas, charging $2 an hour.
Although the price of wi-fi access in public places has recently dropped, it is still prohibitive for the vast majority of Cubans. The average state salary remains about $25 (Â£19) a month.
But for better off Cubans, the move has proved popular.
The government said last year it had 65 wi-fi hotspots in service and expected 80 more to open before the end of 2016.
The hotspots enable Cubans to enjoy much better internet access and a higher-speed connection than most have been used to.
Cuba internet access still severely restricted
Cuba announces broadband home internet project
Cuban internet delivered weekly by hand
Entire families and crowds of young people armed with smart phones, tablets and laptops can be seen at all hours of the day and night hovering around the wi-fi hotspots to get in touch with family and friends in Florida and other parts of the world.
Internet services are provided by state-owned telecoms company Etecsa.
Access to social media sites such as Facebook and Twitter is available at the hotspots - but opposition sites are blocked.
Yet despite the recent improvements, the island still has some of the world's worst connectivity.
That's why the vast majority of Cubans rely on their weekly dose of "Paquete Semanal", an offline selection of material compiled by unidentified curators and delivered every week to subscribers via an unofficial network of distributors using portable hard drives.
Dissidents accuse the government of not providing affordable home internet access for political reasons.
The Cuban government blames the US for the poor state of telecoms infrastructure, which it says is caused by the American economic embargo imposed in the 1960s.
LLM_1:
The move will transform this popular district, frequented by tourists and young locals, into the island’s single largest connectivity zone. Despite this progress, internet penetration remains strikingly low across Cuba, with only about 5% of households having web access, and the government maintains tight control over online content. While many global social media platforms are accessible, opposition sites are routinely blocked. Starting last year, authorities have rolled out dozens of public wi-fi hotspots, initially charging $2 per hour. Although the price has since been reduced slightly, it remains prohibitively expensive for most Cubans, whose average monthly state salary hovers around $25 (approximately £19). For those with greater means, however, the new hotspots have become a welcome resource.

According to official statements from 2015, Cuba had 65 operational wi-fi zones at the time, with plans to launch an additional 80 by the end of 2016. These hotspots offer significantly faster and more reliable connections than what most Cubans have previously experienced. Day and night, the areas around these zones are bustling with entire families and groups of young people, armed with smartphones, tablets, and laptops, eager to video-call relatives in Florida or browse social media. All internet services are channeled through the state-run telecommunications monopoly, Etecsa.

Nevertheless, Cuba continues to suffer from some of the world’s poorest connectivity rates. This gap has given rise to a widespread, informal workaround: the “Paquete Semanal” (Weekly Package), a curated compilation of digital content—from international news and TV shows to software updates—distributed via portable hard drives through an underground network of deliverers. Dissidents argue that the government deliberately keeps home internet unaffordable to stifle political discourse, while officials in Havana blame the decades-old U.S. economic embargo for crippling the country’s telecom infrastructure.

human: To assess the 24-h efficacy of tolterodine extended-release (ER) in patients with overactive bladder (OAB) and urgency urinary incontinence (UUI).We conducted a post hoc analysis of a 12-week, placebo-controlled trial of tolterodine-ER in patients with frequency (> or =8 voids/24 h) and UUI (> or=5 episodes/week) for > or = 6 months. Seven-day bladder diaries were used to record diary endpoints; 24-h diary data were stratified by 6-h periods beginning at midnight.Compared with placebo (508 patients), tolterodine-ER (507 patients) significantly and consistently increased volume voided per void and reduced UUI episodes and micturition frequency during each interval.
LLM_1:
To assess the 24-hour efficacy of tolterodine extended-release (ER) in patients suffering from overactive bladder (OAB) and urgency urinary incontinence (UUI), we conducted a comprehensive post hoc analysis derived from a robust 12-week, placebo-controlled clinical trial. This trial specifically targeted individuals exhibiting symptoms such as frequent urination, defined as eight or more voids within a 24-hour period, and a significant occurrence of UUI, characterized by five or more episodes per week, persisting for a minimum of six months. A critical component of our methodology involved the utilization of detailed seven-day bladder diaries, which allowed for meticulous recording of various diary endpoints related to urinary habits. For a more precise assessment, the 24-hour diary data were systematically stratified into six-hour intervals beginning at midnight, enabling a thorough examination of the medication's effects throughout different times of the day.

Our findings revealed that, in comparison to the placebo group comprising 508 patients, those treated with tolterodine-ER (507 patients) exhibited a statistically significant and consistent enhancement in several key parameters. Notably, there was a marked increase in the volume of urine voided per episode, indicating improved bladder capacity and function. Additionally, we observed a substantial reduction in the frequency of UUI episodes, which can greatly impact quality of life, and a decrease in overall micturition frequency during each specified interval. These results underscore the potential of tolterodine-ER as an effective therapeutic option for managing the symptoms of OAB and UUI, offering patients relief and a better quality of life.
LLM_2:
**Abstract**

This study aims to evaluate the 24-hour efficacy of tolterodine extended-release (ER) in individuals diagnosed with overactive bladder (OAB) and urgency urinary incontinence (UUI) through a detailed post hoc analysis of a comprehensive 12-week, placebo-controlled clinical trial. The trial focused on participants experiencing symptoms, specifically frequent urination—defined as eight or more voids within 24 hours—and notable occurrences of UUI, characterized by five or more episodes weekly for a minimum duration of six months. A pivotal element of our methodology included the implementation of thorough seven-day bladder diaries, facilitating precise documentation of various urinary behavior metrics. To enhance the accuracy of our evaluation, the 24-hour diary data were systematically divided into six-hour intervals commencing at midnight, allowing an in-depth analysis of the medication's effects at different times throughout the day.

The results demonstrated that, relative to the placebo group of 508 patients, the cohort receiving tolterodine-ER (507 patients) exhibited a statistically significant and consistent improvement across multiple key parameters. Specifically, there was a notable increase in the volume of urine voided per episode, indicative of enhanced bladder capacity and functionality. Furthermore, a significant reduction in the frequency of UUI episodes was observed, which is critical for improving patients' quality of life, alongside a decrease in overall micturition frequency across each defined interval. These findings highlight the potential of tolterodine-ER as an effective treatment strategy for alleviating the symptoms associated with OAB and UUI, thereby enhancing patient well-being and quality of life.

`` Dark forces are approaching...'' I take a long slow breath, eyes closed, head hanging, while my face is obscured by my long hair. `` There have been many men who beg for salvation. Many men who plead to be saved. But few men have claimed to have risen... from the dead.'' I let out a long sigh. `` Darkness is soon approaching and with it comes hell's armies. When the bell tolls,'' and I pause again for dramatic effect, `` when it tolls, you will know the truth. 
 `` I have survived Hell. I have fought madmen and the beast incarnate. I have been buried alive by own brother and risen from the grave. And you... you will be unable... to save... yourself. And I will put the final nail in your coffin.'' I raise my head and roll my eyes back. `` And you will.... rest.... in.... peace.''

“Dark forces are approaching…” I draw a long, deliberate breath, my lungs heavy with foreboding. My eyes are closed, my head bowed low, and my face obscured by the curtain of my long hair—a veil woven from the fabric of impending doom. “Many men have cried out for salvation, their voices trembling with desperation. They plead to be liberated from the shackles of their own despair. Yet, few have dared to claim they have risen… from the dead, defying the very laws of nature and fate itself.” 

With a long sigh, I release the weight of knowledge that burdens me. “Darkness draws near, an inky shadow stretching across the land, heralding the arrival of hell’s armies—an unholy legion of tormentors, hell-bent on sowing chaos and despair. When the bell tolls,” I pause for dramatic effect, allowing the silence to pulse with anticipation, “when it tolls, you will know the truth—a truth as chilling as the grave itself.

“I have survived Hell, a personal inferno that tested the very limits of my soul. I have battled madmen, their eyes wild with insanity, and faced the beast incarnate, a creature so vile that its mere presence could twist the strongest wills. I have been buried alive by my own brother, the one I once trusted, only to claw my way back to life through sheer will and the echoes of lost hope. And you… you will find yourself unable to save… yourself, ensnared by your own choices and the darkness you have embraced. I will drive the final nail into your coffin, sealing your fate with the certainty of doom. 

I lift my head, allowing the weight of my words to permeate the cold air, rolling my eyes back to channel the spirits of those who have fought before me. “And you will… rest… in… peace,” a peace that will be as elusive as the light that once graced your soul.

# American Idol Unveils High-Tech Stage as Contestant's Hospitalization Raises Concerns

**LOS ANGELES —** In a major production revamp, *American Idol* premiered a cutting-edge stage and set design for its finals on March 11, 2008, marking a significant upgrade in the show’s visual presentation. The new setup featured advanced lighting systems, dynamic video screens, and innovative moving platforms, raising the bar for televised talent competitions. Alongside the physical overhaul, the series introduced updated graphics, smoother transitions, and a modernized logo, giving the long-running program a fresher, more contemporary look.

The season’s standout moments included contestant David Cook’s widely praised performance of “Billie Jean” during top-ten night. Judges lauded his rock-oriented interpretation and commanding stage presence. However, the performance stirred controversy when the judging panel appeared to credit Cook with the arrangement, despite the introduction noting it was based on Chris Cornell’s version—a gritty rock adaptation distinct from Michael Jackson’s original. Cornell later responded positively to the rendition, telling media he was “flattered” and publicly commending Cook’s vocal intensity and emotional delivery.

In a troubling development, Cook was rushed to the hospital after the top-nine performance show, suffering from heart palpitations and elevated blood pressure. Sources close to the production indicated that the intense pressure and demanding schedule of the competition likely contributed to the health scare. Cook recovered quickly and returned to the competition, but the incident highlighted the physical and emotional toll the show can take on its contestants.

The combination of high-stakes performances, dramatic production upgrades, and behind-the-scenes challenges underscored a pivotal season for *American Idol*, as it balanced innovation with the well-being of its participants.

LLM_1:
Hollywood actor Alan Cumming, Queen guitarist Brian May, and The Libertines’ Peter Doherty are among 21 high-profile figures featured on *The Highland Road*, a sweeping new musical project by 23-year-old Carnoustie-born musician Craig Weir. The ambitious track, which blends spoken-word poetry with layered vocal contributions from an international cast of artists, has drawn praise for its emotional depth and innovative collaborative approach. Each celebrity recorded a single line—often via smartphone—and sent it remotely, contributing to a poetic narrative inspired by a journey Weir and his friend, piper Chris Brown, took along the real Highland Road in British Columbia last year. The resulting composition opens and closes with their original poem, weaving together voices from music, film, and television into a resonant tribute to landscape, identity, and connection.

Weir, a classically trained piper and multi-instrumentalist, said the idea had been percolating for years. “It had been in the back of my mind to have different people contributing their voices to this poem,” he explained. He began by reaching out to artists with whom he’d previously shared the stage or forged personal connections—among them Brian May, Alan Cumming, Kyle Falconer of Dundee band The View, and Peter Doherty. “I really wanted to get Peter involved,” Weir said. “His voice carries such raw authenticity.” The final lineup also includes former AC/DC bassist Mark Evans, veteran broadcaster Lorraine Kelly, and several other Scottish cultural figures, creating a sonic mosaic that spans generations and genres.

Contributions were gathered from across the globe: Doherty recorded his line in Buenos Aires during a South American tour, while Evans laid down his part at a festival in Germany. Most used mobile devices to capture their lines before texting or emailing the audio files to Weir. “At first, it was a gamble,” he admitted. “We weren’t sure how it would sound when pieced together—each person only gave one line.” But in post-production, the fragments coalesced into a seamless and stirring whole, mastered in Glasgow with careful attention to tonal balance and emotional pacing.

The song has already garnered acclaim from its participants. Alan Cumming called it “beautiful” and “really moving,” while Brian May praised the project’s spirit, saying he was “happy to pour a little of my Scottish blood into this epic.” Lorraine Kelly, who contributed her line remotely from London, described the final mix as spine-tingling: “Hearing it all together gave me goosebumps.”

For Weir, the project reflects a dual life split between teaching and performance. By day, he works with students in Angus; by night and weekend, he’s performing on stages from Edinburgh to Los Angeles. “It’s like a Jekyll and Hyde character,” he said with a laugh. “The bell goes on Friday afternoon, and that’s me away—playing around the world.” His pupils, he added, take great interest in his parallel career, especially after he performed alongside Arnold Schwarzenegger at a charity event in Edinburgh and joined Queen onstage for a rendition of *We Will Rock You* at the SSE Hydro. Earlier in his career, he toured with the Bay City Rollers for six dates, further cementing his reputation as a dynamic young force in Scotland’s music scene.

*The Highland Road* stands as both a personal milestone and a testament to the power of artistic collaboration across borders. With its evocative imagery, global voices, and deeply rooted Scottish soul, the piece transcends conventional genre boundaries—offering listeners not just a song, but a journey.
LLM_2:
**Young Scottish Musician Unites Global Stars in Evocative New Project *The Highland Road***

A bold new musical endeavor by 23-year-old Carnoustie-born artist Craig Weir has brought together an international constellation of cultural icons—from Hollywood and rock royalty to Scottish music legends—in a genre-defying tribute to landscape, identity, and human connection.

Titled *The Highland Road*, the ambitious composition blends spoken-word poetry with layered vocal contributions from 21 high-profile figures, including actor Alan Cumming, Queen guitarist Brian May, and The Libertines’ Peter Doherty. Conceived during a reflective journey along British Columbia’s famed Highland Road with piper Chris Brown, the piece is anchored by an original poem written and performed by Weir and Brown, framing a sonic tapestry that spans continents and careers.

Each contributor recorded just one line—often using little more than a smartphone—before sending the audio remotely for post-production in Glasgow. Despite the fragmented process, the final product emerges as a seamless, emotionally resonant narrative, praised by participants for its depth and originality.

“It was a bit of a leap of faith,” admitted Weir, a classically trained piper and multi-instrumentalist. “I’d long imagined weaving voices from different worlds into a single poetic journey. But until we started assembling it, I wasn’t sure how the tones would blend.”

His vision drew on personal connections forged through years of performance: May and Cumming from shared stages, Kyle Falconer of Dundee band The View through mutual tours, and Doherty—whose distinctive voice Weir felt embodied raw emotional truth. “I really wanted Peter involved,” he said. “There’s something unmistakably real in his delivery.”

The roster also features former AC/DC bassist Mark Evans, broadcaster Lorraine Kelly, and a range of prominent Scottish artists, creating a cross-generational chorus that reflects both local pride and global reach. Recordings were captured across time zones: Doherty laid down his line in Buenos Aires mid-tour, Evans contributed from a festival site in Germany, while others—including Kelly—sent their parts from London studios or home setups.

In post-production, meticulous mastering ensured tonal cohesion and emotional pacing, transforming disparate clips into a unified artistic statement. The result has drawn heartfelt responses from those involved. Cumming described the finished work as “beautiful” and “deeply moving.” May, embracing his Scottish heritage, called it an honor to “pour a little of my Scottish blood into this epic.” Kelly, upon hearing the full mix, said it gave her goosebumps.

For Weir, the project mirrors his own dual existence—by day, a dedicated music teacher working with students in Angus; by night and weekend, a touring performer sharing stages with icons like Arnold Schwarzenegger at charity galas and joining Queen for electrifying renditions of *We Will Rock You* at Glasgow’s SSE Hydro. He once toured briefly with the Bay City Rollers, an early milestone that foreshadowed his rising profile.

“It’s like Jekyll and Hyde,” he joked. “The school bell rings on Friday afternoon, and I’m off—performing everywhere from Edinburgh to Los Angeles.” His pupils, he added, follow his parallel career with growing fascination.

With *The Highland Road*, Weir not only marks a personal milestone but redefines what collaborative art can be in the digital age. Fusing evocative imagery, far-flung voices, and a deeply rooted Scottish spirit, the piece transcends genre—it is less a song than an auditory pilgrimage, inviting listeners to travel not just across geography, but within themselves.

LLM_1: Scotland's and Northern Ireland's licensing laws have long been more flexible, allowing local authorities to set pub opening and closing times based on community needs and local customs. This decentralized approach grants councils the discretion to extend hours for special events, accommodate tourist demand, or respond to public safety concerns, fostering a more responsive regulatory environment. In Scotland, this greater autonomy stemmed from the late repeal of wartime licensing laws, which had imposed strict controls on alcohol sales during World War II and remained in force until 1976—significantly later than in England and Wales, where many restrictions were lifted earlier. The prolonged enforcement of these regulations meant that when reform finally came, Scottish policymakers emphasized local choice and gradual liberalization rather than nationwide mandates. As a result, cities like Edinburgh and Glasgow developed distinct licensing cultures, with urban centers often approving later hours compared to rural areas. This regional variation reflects broader societal attitudes toward alcohol consumption and public order, highlighting how historical legacies can shape contemporary policy frameworks.
LLM_2:
---

Licensing laws in Scotland and Northern Ireland have historically been more flexible than those in other parts of the United Kingdom, enabling local authorities to determine pub opening and closing hours based on community needs and local customs. This decentralized approach grants municipal councils discretion to extend operating times for special events, accommodate tourism, or address public safety concerns, resulting in a more adaptive and responsive regulatory framework.

In Scotland, this degree of autonomy can be traced to the relatively late repeal of wartime licensing regulations. During World War II, strict controls on alcohol sales were introduced across the UK; however, while many of these restrictions were lifted earlier in England and Wales, they remained in force in Scotland until 1976. The prolonged enforcement of these measures influenced the trajectory of post-war reform, leading Scottish policymakers to prioritize local decision-making and gradual liberalization over centralized, uniform mandates.

As a consequence, cities such as Edinburgh and Glasgow developed distinct licensing cultures, with urban areas typically authorizing later operating hours compared to rural regions. This regional variation reflects differing societal attitudes toward alcohol consumption and public order, illustrating how historical policy legacies continue to shape contemporary regulatory practices in the UK.

The town was just a place I stopped on my way somewhere else. 
 
 My mother emotionally abused me and my dad physically beat me. All my friends had left years ago. There was n't anything left for me in Anaheim. 
 
 I had left years ago. Off to college, then off to work. I was fairly successful. Had a good paying job, my own house. Had a family in the making. I lived on the opposite coast. 
 
 So why was I here? Back in this town, no longer my home? I was just passing through, on my way to a convention up in San Francisco. 
 
 I am here on nothing more than a coincidence. 
 
 You may call me heartless. There may even be some that think I caused it. I assure you, I got in town today, and I leave today. I have not been here in over half a year. I had no part in the deaths of my parents. 
 
 I come not to pay my respects, but to spit on their graves. 
 
 This is not a place where I stay, where I `` feel'' or cry. It's not a place for me to be comforted. This town is just a place I'm stopping in on my way elsewhere.
LLM_1:
The town was just a place I stopped on my way somewhere else—a dot on the map between the life I’d built and the one I’d fled. The streets still smelled of dry asphalt and orange blossoms, a scent that once meant childhood but now only carried the sharp tang of memory.

My mother’s words had been like slow poison, etching doubt into my bones, while my father’s hands left marks that faded long before the fear did. All my friends had packed their dreams into suitcases years ago, scattering to cities with brighter lights. There was nothing left for me in Anaheim—no unfinished business, no friendly face in a crowd, not even a familiar tree I cared to see again.

I had left years ago, a clean break on a Greyhound bus headed east. College taught me how to think; work taught me how to survive. I climbed quietly, steadily—a good paying job designing software, a cedar-sided house near the Atlantic where the waves erased the shore each night, a partner who laughed easily and a daughter on the way. I built a world an entire continent away from here.

So why was I here? Back on these cracked sidewalks, under this relentless sun? The answer was practical, almost insultingly simple: a convention in San Francisco, a layover, a rental car with a GPS that routed me straight through the past. No destiny, no unfinished symphony—just the indifferent mechanics of travel.

You may call me heartless. There may even be whispers at the diner counter, theories spun over coffee, that I had a hand in what happened. I assure you, my tires touched town limits this morning, and they’ll be rolling out by dusk. I haven’t set foot here in over half a year—not since a Christmas I spent alone in a hotel off the interstate. The deaths of my parents were a closed case, a tragedy of their own making. I had no part in it.

I come not to pay my respects, but to spit on their graves. To let the bitterness, stored and shelved for years, taste the air one last time.

This is not a place where I stay, where I “feel” or cry. It’s not a sanctuary for closure or a stage for forgiveness. The cemetery gates will swing shut behind me, and I’ll merge back onto the highway, the sky deepening to violet ahead. This town is just a fuel stop, a pause in the narrative—a place I’m passing through on my way elsewhere.
LLM_2:
This town was never a destination—just a pause between the life I’d left behind and the one I’d built from scratch. A speck on the map, a breath between chapters. The air still carried that old, haunting perfume of hot asphalt and orange blossoms, a fragrance that once meant home but now only smelled like memory turned sour.

My mother’s voice had seeped into me like a slow stain, etching uncertainty into the marrow of my bones. My father’s hands left bruises that healed long before the fear ever did. All my friends had folded their hopes into luggage years ago, scattering toward cities that glittered with promise. There was nothing left for me in Anaheim—no loose ends, no familiar smile in a crowd, not even a tree whose shade I missed.

I left clean, years back—a one-way ticket east on a Greyhound, chasing the dawn. College taught me how to shape a thought; work taught me how to outlast the day. I climbed without fanfare: a well-paid job crafting code, a cedar house where the Atlantic washed the shore each night, a partner whose laughter came easy, a daughter soon to arrive. I built a life an entire continent away from here.

So why return? Why these sun-bleached sidewalks, this relentless sky? The reason was plain, almost laughably ordinary: a conference in San Francisco, a layover, a rental car whose GPS decided to reroute me straight through yesterday. No fate, no grand reckoning—just the cold, efficient clockwork of travel.

Call me heartless if you want. Let the diner rumors spin—that I had a hand in what happened. But my tires crossed into town this morning, and they’ll be rolling out by dusk. I haven’t been back in over half a year, not since a solitary Christmas in an interstate motel. My parents’ deaths were a closed case, a tragedy of their own making. I played no part.

I didn’t come to lay flowers. I came to spit on their graves. To let the bitterness I’ve kept bottled for years finally breathe the air, one last time.

This is no place for feeling. No sanctuary for closure, no theater for forgiveness. The cemetery gates will close behind me, and I’ll ease back onto the highway, the sky bruising into violet ahead. This town is just a pit stop—a comma in the sentence of my life. A place I pass through on my way to somewhere else.

Australia transports asylum seekers who arrive by boat to off-shore processing centres in Nauru and Papua New Guinea.
An Amnesty International report said this was a "deliberate policy to inflict harm on refugees" and imposes conditions that "amount to torture".
Nauru has previously denied claims of abuse at the refugee centre.
Australia has been repeatedly criticised for its tough policy on refugees and asylum seekers.
It says the policy is necessary to discourage people risking their lives at sea to reach Australian territory.
In the report - titled Island of Despair - Amnesty alleged that many asylum seekers on Nauru have attempted suicide as a result of conditions in indefinite detention.
"The policy that the Australian government is selling to the world as a success is one that it has acknowledged to the public is cruel," it said.
"It has earned Australia unique notoriety as a country that will do everything it can to make sure refugees don't reach its shores and to punish people who dared to try."
Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull told the Australian Broadcasting Corp: "I reject that claim totally."
"It is absolutely false. The Australian government's commitment is compassionate and it's strong."
Approximately 750 people granted refugee status are living on Nauru with 10,000 locals.
The Nauruan government has not responded to the Amnesty report but has previously criticised an TV report that made similar allegations.
The report, by ABC's Four Corners programme, said refugee children were too afraid to attend schools on the island because of high levels of violence and sexual harassment from locals.

This work proposed a mechanism to freeze top layers after supervised pre-training, and re-initialize and retrain the bottom layers. For a model with n layers, when a separation index i is specified, the approach define layer 1~i as bottom layers and i+1~n as top layers. The proposed process enumerate all i from 1 to n-1, compute resulting validation errors respectively, and then pick the i with lowest validation error. The algorithm exhibited significant improvement on WSJ and some minor improvement on CHiME-4.

This work provides some new insight for training ASRs and the observations provide further data points for understanding the training behavior. The layer freezing trick however is relatively well-known, and thus leaving the novelty of the proposed idea to be limited at what layers they choose to freeze.

In algorithm 1 it describes the mechanism as having two loops while it really only needs one loop. The author mentioned they used a simplified version later in the text, and I’ll suggest to update the algorithm block to make it clearer.
