This work proposed a mechanism to freeze the top layers of a neural network after undergoing supervised pre-training, while re-initializing and retraining the bottom layers. Specifically, for a model consisting of n layers, a separation index i is designated, where layers 1 through i are classified as bottom layers, and layers i+1 through n are regarded as top layers. The proposed methodology systematically enumerates all possible values of i from 1 to n-1, calculating the resulting validation errors for each configuration. By analyzing these validation errors, the approach identifies the index i that corresponds to the lowest validation error, thereby optimizing the model's performance. This algorithm demonstrated substantial improvements on the Wall Street Journal (WSJ) dataset, showcasing its efficacy in enhancing automatic speech recognition (ASR) tasks. Additionally, it achieved minor improvements on the CHiME-4 dataset, indicating its versatility across different ASR benchmarks.

This work contributes valuable insights into the training dynamics of ASRs, as the observations offer further empirical data points that help elucidate the underlying training behaviors. However, it is important to note that the technique of freezing layers is relatively well-established in the field, which somewhat constrains the novelty of the proposed approach to the specific layers selected for freezing. The implications of this choice could be further explored to better understand how different configurations impact performance across various datasets.

In Algorithm 1, the mechanism is presented as having two loops, but in reality, it could be effectively implemented with just a single loop. The authors have mentioned a simplified version of the algorithm later in the text, and I recommend updating the algorithm block to reflect this clarification. Such an update would enhance the clarity and precision of the presented methodology, enabling readers to grasp the core concept without unnecessary complexity.

This study proposes a mechanism for freezing the top layers of a neural network following supervised pre-training, while re-initializing and retraining the bottom layers. Specifically, in a model comprising \( n \) layers, a separation index \( i \) is defined, where layers 1 through \( i \) are categorized as bottom layers, and layers \( i+1 \) through \( n \) are classified as top layers. The proposed methodology systematically enumerates all possible values of \( i \) from 1 to \( n-1 \), calculating the corresponding validation errors for each configuration. By analyzing these validation errors, the approach identifies the index \( i \) that yields the lowest validation error, thereby optimizing the model's performance. This algorithm demonstrates substantial improvements on the Wall Street Journal (WSJ) dataset, illustrating its efficacy in enhancing automatic speech recognition (ASR) tasks. Furthermore, it achieves marginal improvements on the CHiME-4 dataset, indicating its versatility across various ASR benchmarks.

This work provides valuable insights into the training dynamics of ASRs, as the observations yield additional empirical data points that elucidate the underlying training behaviors. However, it is pertinent to acknowledge that the technique of freezing layers is relatively well-established within the field, which somewhat limits the novelty of the proposed approach to the specific layers selected for freezing. Further exploration of the implications of this choice could enhance understanding of how different configurations impact performance across diverse datasets.

In Algorithm 1, the mechanism is presented as having two loops; however, it could be effectively implemented using a single loop. The authors reference a simplified version of the algorithm later in the text, and I recommend updating the algorithm block to reflect this clarification. Such an update would enhance the clarity and precision of the presented methodology, enabling readers to comprehend the core concept without unnecessary complexity.

Members of Match.com, eHarmony, Zoosk, Christian Mingle and many others had received emails seeking to steal login details for the sites, said Netcraft.
The net monitoring firm said the emails had been sent from other websites, hacked to hide the senders' identity.
Stolen data would be used to befriend other users in an attempt to trick them into handing over cash, it said.
The phishing campaign against dating sites marked a departure for fraudsters, who typically preferred to target banks, said Paul Mutton, a security analyst at Netcraft who investigated the attacks.
The attacks were "massive", he said, adding that in the past week Netcraft had seen more than 100 compromised sites targeting Match.com alone.
So far, he said, it was not clear how sites were being compromised to host the scripts. Websites and servers run by individuals, small businesses, construction firms and telecom suppliers had all become unwitting hosts of the phishing tools, he added.
Mr Mutton said just one compromised site he had seen was home to about 800 short programs or scripts that targeted many different dating sites. Each script looked like it had been generated by a "kit" bought online.
"Anyone with a very basic knowledge of programming could make use of the kit," he said.
The scripts are used to craft phishing emails that are spammed out to potential victims.
The mails seek to trick people into entering their login names for the dating sites.
If successful, the details are passed on to the legitimate login page of a dating website and are also sent to one of 300 email addresses used by the phishing gang.
Fraudsters were keen to steal login details for accounts so they could avoid paying the charges dating sites levied before users could swap messages with other members, said Mr Mutton.
Using on-site messages the fraudsters hope to befriend others and then try to extract cash to help pay for a non-existent medical condition or to aid fictitious relatives.
Significant amounts of cash could be stolen this way, said Mr Mutton, pointing to the case of Karen and Tracy Vasseur, of Colorado, who were jailed in 2013 for stealing more than $1m (Â£590,000) from 374 people using dating-site scams.

### Cybersecurity Alert: Major Dating Platforms Targeted by Sophisticated Phishing Scheme

Members of popular dating services, including Match.com, eHarmony, Zoosk, and Christian Mingle, have become targets of a sophisticated phishing scheme designed to steal login credentials, according to a report from cybersecurity firm Netcraft. The fraudulent emails, which appear to originate from legitimate sources, have been traced back to compromised websites that have been hacked to conceal the true identity of the senders. This alarming trend underscores the lengths to which cybercriminals will go to exploit unsuspecting users, as the stolen data is often used to foster seemingly genuine relationships with other online daters, ultimately leading to financial deception.

Paul Mutton, a security analyst at Netcraft who has been closely monitoring these attacks, emphasized that this phishing campaign marks a significant shift in tactics for fraudsters, who have traditionally focused their efforts on financial institutions. "The scale of these attacks is massive," Mutton stated, revealing that in just the past week, Netcraft identified over 100 compromised sites targeting Match.com alone. This extensive operation highlights the vulnerability not only of dating platforms but also of numerous smaller websites that have unwittingly become hosts for these malicious phishing tools.

While the precise methods of compromise remain unclear, Mutton noted that a diverse range of websites—including individual businesses, construction firms, and telecom providers—have all been infiltrated, serving as reluctant accomplices in the phishing campaign. One particularly concerning case involved a single compromised site that hosted approximately 800 scripts specifically designed to target various dating platforms. The sheer volume of these scripts indicates a troubling trend, as they appear to be generated from readily available "kits" that can be purchased online, enabling even those with minimal programming skills to launch their own phishing attacks.

These scripts play a crucial role in crafting deceptive phishing emails that are indiscriminately sent out to potential victims, aiming to trick them into revealing their login information. Once a user unwittingly submits their credentials, the information is seamlessly redirected to the legitimate login page of the dating site, while simultaneously being transmitted to one of the 300 designated email addresses controlled by the phishing syndicate.

Fraudsters are increasingly motivated to steal login details, as doing so opens the door to a range of exploitation opportunities, from accessing personal information to perpetrating financial fraud.

Eoin Morgan's side broke the world record for an ODI score when they posted 444-3 against Pakistan.
"It was brilliant," Fraser told BBC Radio 5 live. "But you want to see a contest between bat and ball."
England have now won the series.
They triumphed in the first three of their five scheduled ODIs against Pakistan, with the fourth on Thursday, 1 September.
England's innings contained 16 sixes - the most they have ever scored in an ODI innings - and was underpinned by opener Alex Hales' 171 off 122 balls, their highest ever ODI individual score.
Pakistan left-arm paceman Wahab Riaz finished with figures of 0-110, the second most expensive in ODI history.
"It was great to watch," said Fraser, a former England bowler. "It was lovely watching the England players performing as they are.
"Obviously you want to see your team do well. But it can become a bit boring when the ball keeps going for four and six."
Fraser said he did not want to sound "negative" or "miserable" after an "unbelievable night of cricket", but added: "If this becomes the norm, who's going to want to bowl in the future?
"There are very few places a bowler seems to be able to go now. As a bowler you want to be getting wickets through skill rather than batsman error.
"All a bowler is trying to do is hide 60 balls. Sometimes bowlers are running in, bowling a good spell and still going for 65 from 10 overs."
Asked if there was any solution, Fraser replied: "The genie is out of the bottle. People turn up to see runs in white ball cricket, you know what the game is about - big scores."

**England Shatter ODI Record with 444 for 3 Against Pakistan in Dominant Trent Bridge Display**

*By [News Desk]*  
*Trent Bridge, September 1* — England’s cricket team has rewritten the record books in spectacular fashion, posting the highest innings total in One Day International history: **444 for 3** against Pakistan at Trent Bridge. The staggering score not only secured a commanding victory but also underscored the transformative power of modern batting, as boundaries flowed with relentless frequency under clear skies and on a benign pitch.

At the heart of the demolition was opener **Alex Hales**, whose career-best 171 off just 122 balls lit up the Nottingham ground. His explosive knock—featuring 22 fours and five sixes—marked England’s highest individual ODI score and set the tone for an innings that saw the hosts launch an unprecedented assault on the Pakistani bowling attack. In total, England cleared the ropes 16 times, surpassing their previous record for sixes in a single ODI.

The sheer ferocity and precision of England’s batting left Pakistan’s bowlers demoralized and searching for answers. Left-arm seamer **Wahab Riaz** endured a particularly punishing spell, conceding 110 runs from his 10 overs without claiming a wicket—the second most expensive figures in ODI history. The performance highlighted growing concerns about the balance between bat and ball in white-ball cricket, where flat pitches and aggressive shot-making have increasingly tilted the game in favor of batters.

Former England fast bowler **Angus Fraser**, now a respected commentator, praised the quality of the hitting but sounded a note of caution over the long-term health of the format. Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live, he said: *“It was brilliant to watch—there’s no denying the skill and confidence on display. But you want to see a contest between bat and ball. When the boundary comes every other ball, it risks becoming one-dimensional.”*

Fraser, who took 209 ODI wickets during his playing days, emphasized the psychological toll on bowlers in such lopsided contests. *“As a bowler, you want to feel like you can earn wickets through skill and strategy,”* he noted. *“Right now, too many are just trying to survive—running in hard, bowling well, and still going for 65 in ten. It can feel like all you’re doing is hiding 60 balls.”*

With this win, England clinched an unassailable 3-0 lead in the five-match series, having dominated each of the opening three ODIs with clinical performances. While the fourth match is scheduled for Thursday, the outcome of the series is already decided, allowing both teams to shift focus toward experimentation and player assessment in the remaining fixtures.

The historic total has sparked widespread celebration among fans and pundits alike, but also renewed debate about the future direction of limited-overs cricket. While high-scoring thrillers draw crowds and boost viewership, critics warn that repeated mismatches could discourage aspiring fast bowlers and erode the sport’s competitive equilibrium.

*“The genie is out of the bottle,”* Fraser acknowledged. *“People come to white-ball games expecting big scores and fireworks. That’s the product now. But we have to ask: if this becomes the norm, who will want to bowl?”*

For now, England stands atop the ODI world—not just in rankings, but in records—after a performance that was as dominant as it was historic. Yet, amid the applause, a quiet concern lingers: in the pursuit of entertainment, is cricket losing its balance?

LLM_2:
# *American Idol*’s Judge Carousel: A Decade of High-Profile Exits, Drama, and Reinvention

The eighth season of *American Idol* introduced a new voice to the judging panel: Kara DioGuardi, a Grammy-nominated songwriter and producer known for hits with stars like Kelly Clarkson and Pink. As the show’s fourth judge, DioGuardi brought industry expertise, but her stint was brief—lasting only two seasons—before she exited ahead of Season 10 amid behind-the-scenes changes.

Her arrival coincided with another major shift. Original judge Paula Abdul, beloved for her empathetic feedback and choreography background, left before Season 9 after contract talks with producers broke down. Her departure closed a chapter for the series and prompted the show to recruit Emmy-winning talk show host Ellen DeGeneres as her replacement. Yet DeGeneres’s humor and non-music background proved an awkward fit; she stepped down after just one season, underscoring the difficulty of placing a non-musician in a critic’s chair.

The panel’s most seismic change came on January 11, 2010, when sharp-tongued cornerstone judge Simon Cowell announced he would leave to launch the U.S. version of *The X Factor* in 2011. Cowell’s exit forced a major reinvention. For Season 10, producers brought in global icon Jennifer Lopez and Aerosmith frontman Steven Tyler. Their star power briefly boosted ratings, but both left after two seasons, citing busy schedules and other projects.

That led to a full overhaul in Season 12. Randy Jackson—the last original judge—was joined by three new faces: pop diva Mariah Carey, rap superstar Nicki Minaj, and country artist Keith Urban. The season drew headlines for reported clashes between Carey and Minaj, and despite the buzz, both women departed after one season. Jackson, meanwhile, announced he would step down as a judge after 12 seasons, moving into a mentoring role.

Amid the turbulence, Keith Urban became a steadying presence. He returned for Season 13 as the only holdover from the previous panel, joined by Jennifer Lopez—back after a short break—and former mentor Harry Connick, Jr., whose musical knowledge and quick wit resonated with viewers. The trio clicked, fostering a rare stretch of stability as they returned for Seasons 14 and 15, offering fans consistency after years of revolving-judge drama.

human: Lipocalin-2 (LCN2) was originally isolated from human neutrophils and termed neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL). However, the functions of LCN2 and the cell types that are primarily responsible for LCN2 production remain unclear. To address these issues, hepatocyte-specific Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(Hep-/-)) mice were generated and subjected to bacterial infection (with Klesbsiella pneumoniae or Escherichia coli) or partial hepatectomy (PHx). Studies of Lcn2(Hep-/-) mice revealed that hepatocytes contributed to 25% of the low basal serum level of LCN2 protein (∼ 62 ng/mL) but were responsible for more than 90% of the highly elevated serum LCN2 protein level (∼ 6,000 ng/mL) postinfection and more than 60% post-PHx (∼ 700 ng/mL). Interestingly, both Lcn2(Hep-/-) and global Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(-/-)) mice demonstrated comparable increases in susceptibility to infection with K. pneumoniae or E. coli. These mice also had increased enteric bacterial translocation from the gut to the mesenteric lymph nodes and exhibited reduced liver regeneration after PHx. Treatment with interleukin (IL)-6 stimulated hepatocytes to produce LCN2 in vitro and in vivo. Hepatocyte-specific ablation of the IL-6 receptor or Stat3, a major downstream effector of IL-6, markedly abrogated LCN2 elevation in vivo. Furthermore, chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assay revealed that STAT3 was recruited to the promoter region of the Lcn2 gene upon STAT3 activation by IL-6.
LLM_1:
Lipocalin-2 (LCN2) was originally isolated from human neutrophils and termed neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL). However, the precise functions of LCN2, as well as the specific cell types primarily responsible for its production, remain subjects of ongoing investigation and debate within the scientific community. To address these critical issues, researchers generated hepatocyte-specific Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(Hep-/-)) mice, which were then subjected to bacterial infections with pathogens such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli, or underwent partial hepatectomy (PHx). Studies involving Lcn2(Hep-/-) mice revealed that hepatocytes contribute to approximately 25% of the low basal serum level of LCN2 protein, measured at around 62 ng/mL. However, their role becomes significantly pronounced during stress conditions, as they are responsible for over 90% of the sharply elevated serum LCN2 protein levels, which rise to approximately 6,000 ng/mL following bacterial infection, and account for more than 60% of the post-PHx levels, which reach around 700 ng/mL. 

Interestingly, both Lcn2(Hep-/-) and global Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(-/-)) mice exhibited similar increases in susceptibility to infections caused by K. pneumoniae or E. coli, highlighting the importance of LCN2 in the immune response. Additionally, these knockout mice demonstrated increased enteric bacterial translocation from the gut to the mesenteric lymph nodes, which could have implications for understanding the relationship between gut health and systemic immune responses. Furthermore, they exhibited impaired liver regeneration following PHx, suggesting that LCN2 plays a vital role in hepatic recovery and repair processes. 

In vitro and in vivo studies indicated that treatment with interleukin (IL)-6 significantly stimulated hepatocytes to produce LCN2, establishing a crucial link between cytokine signaling and LCN2 production. Notably, hepatocyte-specific ablation of the IL-6 receptor or Stat3, which is a major downstream effector of IL-6 signaling, markedly reduced LCN2 elevation in vivo, underscoring the role of the IL-6/STAT3 pathway in regulating LCN2 levels. Additionally, chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays revealed that STAT3 was recruited to the promoter region of the Lcn2 gene upon activation by IL-6, providing molecular insight into the transcriptional regulation of LCN2. This regulatory mechanism highlights the intricate interplay between inflammatory signaling and the hepatic response, suggesting that targeting the IL-6/STAT3 axis may have therapeutic potential in conditions characterized by altered LCN2 levels and associated pathological processes.
LLM_2:
Lipocalin-2 (LCN2), initially identified in human neutrophils and designated as neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin (NGAL), continues to be a focal point of research regarding its functional roles and the specific cell types responsible for its synthesis. To elucidate these critical aspects, investigators developed hepatocyte-specific Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(Hep-/-)) mice, subjecting them to bacterial infections from pathogens such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Escherichia coli, in addition to partial hepatectomy (PHx). Analyses of Lcn2(Hep-/-) mice indicated that hepatocytes contribute approximately 25% to the baseline serum levels of LCN2 protein, estimated at 62 ng/mL. Notably, their contribution escalates significantly under stress conditions, accounting for over 90% of the markedly increased serum LCN2 levels—approximately 6,000 ng/mL post-infection—and over 60% of the levels observed after PHx, which rise to around 700 ng/mL.

Moreover, both Lcn2(Hep-/-) and global Lcn2 knockout (Lcn2(-/-)) mice displayed comparable increases in susceptibility to infections from K. pneumoniae and E. coli, underscoring the critical role of LCN2 in immune responses. These knockout models also exhibited heightened enteric bacterial translocation from the gut to the mesenteric lymph nodes, offering insights into the connection between gut health and systemic immune functionality. Additionally, impaired liver regeneration was noted following PHx, indicating that LCN2 is essential for hepatic recovery and repair mechanisms.

In vitro and in vivo investigations demonstrated that interleukin (IL)-6 treatment significantly enhanced LCN2 production in hepatocytes, establishing an important association between cytokine signaling and LCN2 synthesis. Furthermore, the hepatocyte-specific deletion of the IL-6 receptor or Stat3—a principal downstream mediator of IL-6 signaling—dramatically diminished LCN2 levels in vivo, emphasizing the regulatory function of the IL-6/STAT3 pathway on LCN2 expression. Chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays further revealed that STAT3 is recruited to the promoter region of the Lcn2 gene upon IL-6 activation, providing a molecular framework for understanding LCN2 transcriptional regulation. This regulatory pathway illustrates the complex interaction between inflammatory signaling and hepatic response, suggesting that targeting the IL-6/STAT3 axis could offer therapeutic strategies for conditions associated with dysregulated LCN2 levels and related pathological processes.

Title: Evaluation of GnRH Antagonist Therapy in Managing Severe Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHGS)

Abstract:

Ovarain hyperstimuation syndrome (OHS), a condition associated with embryo transfer, poses significant clinical challenges. To assess the efficacy of high-dose gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist administration in treating severe OHGs, we conducted a prospective comparative trial involving six infertility patients who developed OHs symptoms, characterized by ascites and hemoconcentration, following embryo transplantation. Patients received 5.0 mg (initial dose) and 4.9 mg and/or 3.4 mg of cetorilide (additional doses), an antagonist of Serono, Madrid, Spain. The control cohort consisted five patients with OHG who received only standard care.

Clinical evaluations and ultrasound assessments revealed that the six treated subjects exhibited significant reductions in estrogen (E) levels and faster peritonial fluid regression compared with those receiving supportive treatment. Notably, hematocrit levels in patients undergoing GnHR antagonist infusion remained steady, whereas those in controls increased. In light of two treated patient's deteriorating clinical status, they received additional dosages of Gnr antagonist on day 1. All treated participants avoided invasive interventions such a paracentesis.

Our preliminary findings suggest that GnRh antagonist may mitigate severe symptomatology of severe OGHS, warranting further investigation to validate its therapeutic potential. However, due to a relatively modest sample, future, well-designed studies are necessary to establish the safety, efficacy, optimal dosing, of these antagonist, while exploring its implications for improving treatment outcomes in OHCS patients.

Further research on this intervention may reduce reliance on invasive treatments like parcntesis and provide healthcare professionals with an enhanced, compassionate approach to care, ultimately, offering women with OHCs a less burdensome and more accessible treatment plan. Hence, conducting larger-scale clinical trails to evaluate the utility of GRH antagonist as an OHCG treatment is indispensable. If proven effective & safe, Grr antagonist could contribute significantly to advancements in clinical care & improve lives by providing a manageable, less-invasive treatment path for women afflicted with OGCS. Thus, exploring the therapeutic efficacy & potential of GN antagonist is of utmost importance.  Consequently the further studies on GR antagonist are highly advocated.

The ploughman's lunch became popular in the late 1960s. In the late 1960s "chicken in a basket", a portion of roast chicken with chips, served on a napkin, in a wicker basket became popular due to its convenience.
LLM_1: In the 1950s, many British pubs operated under traditional ownership models where the landlord and his family often managed daily affairs, and it was common for the proprietor’s wife to prepare simple, hearty meals in the back kitchen. One such offering was "a pie and a pint," a no-frills yet satisfying combination that catered to working-class patrons during lunchtime hours. These individual steak and ale pies were typically baked fresh on-site using leftover Sunday roast meat, slow-cooked with onions and stout in small ceramic dishes, then topped with flaky pastry. The dish required minimal equipment—often just a basic oven or hotplate—and could be served quickly, making it ideal for the midday rush. As pub culture evolved, so did the menu. By the late 1960s, the Ploughman’s lunch emerged as a nostalgic nod to rural English life, promoted by cheese manufacturers and regional breweries as part of a marketing campaign to boost dairy consumption. This cold meal usually included a wedge of cheddar, pickled onions, a crusty roll, and sometimes apple slices or pork pie, all arranged simply on a plate—an embodiment of rustic simplicity amid growing interest in heritage foods. Around the same time, another novelty took hold: "chicken in a basket." Roast chicken portions, often dark meat for affordability, were paired with thick-cut chips (fries) and presented on a paper napkin inside a woven wicker basket, mimicking picnic ware. The presentation was novel and practical, allowing customers to eat informally without the need for table service, which appealed to younger, more mobile patrons and reflected the era’s broader shift toward casual dining. This trend also coincided with increased poultry availability and changing attitudes toward convenience food, marking a transition from homemade pub fare to more standardized, market-driven offerings.

---

In the 1950s, many British pubs operated under traditional ownership models, with publicans and their families typically managing daily operations. It was common for the landlord’s wife to prepare simple, hearty meals in a back kitchen, catering primarily to working-class patrons during lunch hours. A popular offering at the time was "a pie and a pint"—a straightforward combination of an individual steak and ale pie served with a pint of beer. These pies were usually baked on-site using leftover meat from Sunday roasts, slow-cooked with onions and stout, and enclosed in flaky pastry within small ceramic dishes. Requiring only basic kitchen equipment such as an oven or hotplate, the dish could be prepared and served quickly, making it well-suited to the midday rush.

As pub culture evolved in the following decades, so too did pub menus. By the late 1960s, the Ploughman’s lunch emerged as a deliberate evocation of rural English life. Promoted through a joint marketing campaign by cheese producers and regional breweries to encourage dairy consumption, the meal became emblematic of a nostalgic return to traditional fare. Typically consisting of a wedge of cheddar cheese, pickled onions, a crusty roll, and occasionally apple slices or a portion of pork pie, the Ploughman’s lunch was presented simply on a plate, reflecting ideals of rustic simplicity amid a growing public interest in heritage foods.

Around the same period, another novelty gained popularity: "chicken in a basket." This dish featured portions of roast chicken—often dark meat for cost reasons—served with thick-cut chips (fries) on a paper napkin placed inside a woven wicker basket, mimicking picnic-style presentation. The format offered a casual, informal dining experience that required no table service, appealing particularly to younger, more mobile customers. Its rise coincided with increased poultry availability and shifting attitudes toward convenience foods, marking a broader transition in pub cuisine from homemade preparations to more standardized, commercially influenced offerings.

---

Hey everyone, welcome to Summerville, SC—Day Who-Knows-How-Many on tour with Paulson. Honestly, keeping track of the days feels impossible when every 24 hours brings something completely unexpected. These guys in Paulson aren’t just bandmates—they’ve become family, and getting to share a stage (and a van, and a gas station meal, and way too many motels) with them night after night has been nothing short of a dream. Some shows have lit up the room like fireworks; others? Well, let’s just say the crowd was polite. But that’s the beauty of life on the road—you never know what you’re gonna get, and that uncertainty is part of the magic.

We wake up each morning not knowing if we’ll play to a packed house or end up serenading a bartender and a confused dog, and honestly? We love it. There’s freedom in not having a script, in letting the journey unfold one highway exit at a time. That said, the last few gigs have come with their own special kind of challenge—thanks to me and my brilliant decision-making skills. So here’s how I turned myself into a cautionary tale: One late night, after one too many stories and not enough common sense, I dared Logan, Paulson’s fearless frontman, to jump from one rooftop to another. He did it. Clean. Like some indie rock parkour legend. Naturally, my ego kicked in. If he could do it, why couldn’t I?

Spoiler: I couldn’t.

I didn’t make the leap. Instead, I caught the edge with my left hand while my throat slammed down on the roof’s lip. Woke up the next morning sounding like a chain-smoking frog, barely able to croak out a hello, let alone sing. My left hand? Stiff, swollen, and generally unimpressed with my life choices. Playing guitar for the next few shows became an act of pure stubbornness—fumbling through chords, relying on muscle memory and sheer willpower. Singing? Forget it. I mouthed lyrics like a sad goldfish while the crowd sang back louder than ever. And honestly? That support made all the difference.

But between the chaos and the consequences, we’ve still managed to keep things light. Case in point: my hair. Oh man, the hair saga. Long before we hit the road, I chopped it into what can only be described as a Tony Hawk meets Rosie O’Donnell hybrid—equal parts skater punk and 90s sitcom mom. I left it like that on purpose, fully expecting shenanigans, and boy, did we deliver. Midway through the tour, we stopped by my aunt’s place outside DC, where we decided—because clearly wisdom isn’t our strong suit—the perfect idea was to dye it blonde. Enter Alex from Paulson, armed with bleach and zero precision. He somehow missed a few patches, leaving behind these glorious brown islands in a sea of platinum. At first, it looked like a science experiment gone wrong. Then we leaned in.

We trimmed it into a full-on mohawk—“hawk,” as we now reverently call it. After a solid ten minutes of hairspray, spit, and prayer, we got it to stand up like a middle finger to bad decisions and gravity alike. The result? Iconic. There’s a photo floating around somewhere that perfectly captures the glory: me, grinning like an idiot, looking like a punk-rock rooster. Absolute perfection. As for what’s next? I’m thinking a clean shave. Go full bald. Embrace the marble rye look—pale, speckled, and somehow still stylish. Because if this tour has taught me anything, it’s that reinvention is always possible. Even when you’re hoarse, sore, and your hair looks like a crime scene.

The goal was to elevate the storytelling without losing the raw, candid charm that makes it feel personal and relatable.

**Welcome to Summerville, SC — Day ??? on Tour with Paulson**

Hey everyone,

Welcome to *somewhere* in South Carolina—possibly Summerville, though at this point, I’ve lost track of both days and time zones. When you're living out of a van, surviving on gas station coffee and questionable diner fries, calendars become more suggestion than rule.

Touring with Paulson has been nothing short of surreal. These aren’t just bandmates anymore—they’re family. We’ve shared stages, motels, backseats, and far too many awkward bathroom stops. And honestly? It’s been a dream. Some nights, the energy explodes the second we hit the stage—crowds singing every word, lights flashing, hearts racing. Other shows? Let’s just say the bartender was our most enthusiastic fan… and even he looked mildly confused.

But that unpredictability? That’s the magic of life on the road. You wake up not knowing if you’ll play to 500 people or serenade a sleeping dog and a disinterested barista—and somehow, you love it all the same. There’s freedom in the chaos, beauty in the lack of a script. Every show is its own story, unfolding one highway exit at a time.

That said, the last few gigs came with an extra side of *consequence*—courtesy of yours truly and my world-class decision-making skills.

Here’s how I turned myself into a cautionary tale:

One late night, fueled by adrenaline, nostalgia, and zero common sense, I dared Logan—the fearless frontman of Paulson, indie rock legend, part-time parkour enthusiast—to jump from one rooftop to another.

He did it. Clean. Like a scene ripped from a coming-of-age movie where the lead finally *gets* it.

Naturally, my ego stepped in.  
*If he can do it… why can’t I?*

Spoiler: I couldn’t.

I didn’t make the leap. Instead, I caught the edge with my left hand while my throat slammed into the roof’s sharp lip. The result? Waking up sounding like a chain-smoking frog who lost a fight with a gravel truck. Singing? Forget it. Saying “hello” was a challenge. As for my hand—it’s stiff, swollen, and currently filing a formal complaint against me.

Playing guitar over the past few shows became an act of sheer stubbornness: fumbling through chords, leaning hard on muscle memory, and praying no one noticed the missed notes. Singing? I mouthed lyrics like a sad goldfish while the crowd carried the weight for me. And you know what? Their voices made all the difference. That support—the way they sang louder when I couldn’t—was everything.

Amid the chaos, we still found room for joy. Case in point: my hair.

Long before tour kicked off, I hacked my hair into what can only be described as a *Tony Hawk meets Rosie O’Donnell* aesthetic—equal parts skater punk and '90s sitcom mom. I kept it that way on purpose, fully expecting shenanigans. And boy, did we deliver.

Midway through the tour, we stopped by my aunt’s place outside D.C., where, in a moment of collective poor judgment, we decided the *perfect* idea was to bleach it blonde.

Enter Alex from Paulson: bleach in hand, confidence high, precision? Nonexistent.

He somehow missed entire patches, leaving behind proud little islands of brown in a sea of platinum disaster. At first glance, it looked like a science experiment gone horribly wrong. Then—inspiration struck.

We leaned *in*.  

We chopped it into a full-on mohawk—now known among us as “the hawk.” After ten minutes of hairspray, spit, and genuine prayer, we got it standing upright like a middle finger to bad decisions, gravity, and societal norms alike.

The result? Iconic.

There’s a photo floating around—probably already immortalized in meme form—of me grinning like an idiot, looking like a punk-rock rooster ready to crow defiance at dawn. Absolute perfection.

As for what’s next? I’m thinking… bald. Full shave. Go full *marble rye*: pale, speckled, and inexplicably stylish. Because if this tour has taught me anything, it’s that reinvention is always possible—even when you’re hoarse, sore, and your hair looks like a crime scene.

This journey hasn’t been perfect. But it’s been real. And sometimes, that’s more than enough.

Catch us at the next stop. Bring earplugs, snacks, and maybe a first-aid kit.  
We’ll bring the noise—and the stories.

—[Your Name]

---

Between 1590 and 1712, the Dutch not only possessed one of the strongest and fastest navies in the world, but they also demonstrated remarkable strategic prowess in maritime warfare and commerce. This naval dominance enabled them to orchestrate a series of varied conquests across distant territories, effectively breaking the Portuguese sphere of influence in the Indian Ocean and the Orient. The Dutch captured key trading posts and fortified locations, such as Malacca and Ceylon, which were pivotal in controlling the spice trade—a lucrative market that significantly enriched the Dutch economy. 

Additionally, the Dutch were deeply involved in the transatlantic slave trade, establishing trading routes that facilitated the transport of enslaved Africans to plantations in the Americas and the Caribbean. This grim enterprise not only contributed to their wealth but also underscored the darker aspects of their maritime expansion. Furthermore, their activities extended to the Pacific, where they engaged in trade with indigenous populations and sought to establish their presence in the lucrative fur and sandalwood trades in regions like New Zealand and the islands of Indonesia. 

Their navy's agility and innovative shipbuilding techniques, including the construction of the fluyt—a type of sailing vessel designed for cargo transport—allowed the Dutch to dominate trade routes and outmaneuver competitors, not just from Portugal but also from England and France. This period marked the Netherlands as a formidable global power, influencing international trade patterns and establishing a colonial empire that would have lasting impacts on world history.

What's with all the freaking fights this week? Can people just not be friends? Seriously. When you find yourself in conflicts with others, it often serves as a revealing moment where you can truly identify who your real friends are. Over the past couple of months, I’ve witnessed a mix of both positive and negative traits in the people around me. It’s quite anomalous how you can think you know someone inside and out, only to discover that they are, in fact, a completely different person than you believed. This experience has made me realize that you can’t judge someone solely based on what you’ve heard or the surface-level impressions they create; you really have to invest time in getting to know them on a deeper level.

It’s baffling how some individuals seem to change their entire demeanor or personality just to fit in with others. I suppose this phenomenon is part of the growing-up process—a journey filled with lessons learned through experience. But it raises an important question: Are they really living their lives authentically? Sure, they might be breathing and going through the motions of each day, but take a moment to ponder this: Are they genuinely being themselves? Sometimes, the person who walks through the door in the morning is not the real “you” but rather a version crafted to meet the expectations of society or peers. 

It all boils down to the individual's capacity for authenticity. If you’re spending your life pretending to be someone you’re not, then you’re not truly living. It’s sad because, in doing so, you’re denying others the chance to know the real you. And do you really want that? Sure, we all crave admiration and validation from our friends and peers, but if that admiration is based on a facade, then what’s the point? It doesn’t contribute to your growth as a person. Instead, it may just be a shallow echo, leaving you feeling empty inside.

It’s amusing that I find myself ranting about such seemingly straightforward concepts when, in reality, they’re rooted in common sense. Be yourself. That’s the mantra we’ve heard our entire lives, yet it’s worth considering that who we think we are might not reflect the truth of our identity. Perhaps we aren’t as conspicuous as we believe; maybe we’re just another blurred face in the crowd, struggling to stand out in a world that often celebrates conformity. Would it really kill us to embrace our differences? 

Right now, it seems like everyone is experimenting with new styles and trends, but if everyone is doing the same thing, then how can it be considered original? What’s left for us to explore? Maybe this is just me overthinking things, but isn’t it worth a moment of reflection? Nowadays, people parade around claiming they have their own unique style, yet when you examine these groups closely, you’ll find that we mostly dress similarly or adopt the same trends. So, what does that make us? Special or not? For many, this conformity acts as a comforting security blanket, allowing them to blend into the background and avoid the spotlight. But there are those who dare to be different—those who take pride in standing apart from the crowd and defining their own paths. To me, that’s the true way to live.

Whether people label me as a poser or not, I’d love for someone to explain how I’m posing. What exactly am I pretending to be? The way I dress, how I act, and what I do—all of that is simply me, unfiltered and unapologetic. If others disapprove, that’s perfectly fine. I don’t criticize them for their choices or lifestyles. People have diverse opinions and personalities, which means not everyone will appreciate what you do. But does that make their perspective the ‘right’ one? Perhaps what’s deemed ‘cool’ isn’t always what’s best for you. So what if you catch a few glares in the hallway from people who don’t understand your individuality? At least you’re not just another indistinguishable face in the crowd or a whisper lost in the noise. 

Dare to be different—what’s the worst that could happen? Embrace your uniqueness and let your true self shine. After all, it’s your life to live, not a script to follow.

Seriously, can’t people just be friends? Lately, I've noticed an alarming number of conflicts among those around me. These moments often serve as revealing experiences, showing us who our true friends really are. Over the past few months, I’ve observed both positive and negative traits in people I thought I knew well. It’s astonishing how you can think you understand someone completely, only to find out they’re not at all who you thought they were. This realization has taught me a valuable lesson: you can’t judge someone based solely on hearsay or superficial impressions. True understanding requires time and effort to delve deeper.

It’s baffling to see how some individuals shift their entire demeanor just to fit in. I suppose this is part of growing up—a journey filled with lessons learned through experience. But it raises an important question: Are they genuinely living authentically? Sure, they might be going through the motions of daily life, but let’s pause and consider: Are they really being themselves? Sometimes, the person who walks through the door in the morning is not the "real you," but rather a version crafted to meet societal or peer expectations.

Ultimately, it all comes down to our ability to be authentic. If you’re spending your life pretending to be someone else, you’re not truly living. It’s disheartening because, in doing so, you’re denying others the opportunity to know the real you. Is that what you want? We all crave admiration and validation from our friends and peers, but if that validation is based on a facade, what’s the point? It contributes little to your growth and may leave you feeling empty inside.

It’s amusing that I find myself ranting about what should be common sense: Be yourself. We’ve heard this mantra our entire lives, yet it’s worth considering that who we believe we are might not reflect our true identity. Perhaps we’re not as conspicuous as we think; maybe we’re just another blurred face in the crowd, struggling to stand out in a world that often celebrates conformity. Would it really hurt to embrace our differences?

Right now, it seems like everyone is experimenting with new styles and trends. But if everyone is doing the same thing, can it truly be called original? What’s left for us to explore? Maybe I’m overthinking things, but isn’t it worth a moment of reflection? Nowadays, people parade around claiming to have their unique style, yet when you look closely, you’ll see we often dress similarly or adopt the same trends. So what does that make us? Special or not? For many, this conformity acts as a comforting security blanket, allowing them to blend into the background and avoid the spotlight. But there are those who dare to stand out—who take pride in defining their own paths. To me, that’s the true way to live.

Whether people label me a poser or not, I’d love to hear someone explain how I’m pretending. What exactly am I faking? The way I dress, act, and live is simply me—unfiltered and unapologetic. If others disapprove, that’s perfectly fine. I don’t criticize them for their choices or lifestyles. People have diverse opinions and personalities, which means not everyone will appreciate what you do. But does that make their perspective the ‘right’ one? Perhaps what’s deemed ‘cool’ isn't always what's best for you. So what if you catch a few glares from those who don’t understand your individuality? At least you’re not just another indistinguishable face in the crowd or a whisper lost in the noise.

Dare to be different—what’s the worst that could happen? Embrace your uniqueness and let your true self shine. After all, it’s your life to live, not a script to follow.

Feel free to let me know if you'd like any further adjustments!

I did n't know if I had the courage to do this, but... 
 I finally got the courage to sit in the van again. The van where Will died. 
 
 The snow crunched underneath the weight of my boots as I trekked through the front yard towards the street. Flakes crystallized and clung to my jacket. Heavy snowfall, the first of the season. 
 
 It was early December, seven months since Will overdosed on his anti-depressant pills in the middle of the night; I was oblivious, fast asleep on his living room couch. Seven months since I found him sprawled out on his bedroom floor, his mouth agape. Seven months since I sped down the parkway, faster than summer heat lightning, towards the hospital... his lifeless body slumped in the passenger seat: cold skin, vacant eyes still open, peering endlessly into the abyss of what could have been… 
 
 A small breeze accompanied by tiny flurries whipped through me, right through me, my skin a pale, sheer sheet of nothingness. The neighborhood remained quiet and still, save for the Jenkinson ’ s dog barking after a squirrel two doors down. Middle of the day, nobody was home on my street. 
 
 My hands shook from the cold as I removed the car key from my jacket pocket and jammed it into the door to unlock the van. The door took a few extra pulls to open -- it had remained untouched since that day. I wouldn ’ t let Mom or Dad or Nad drive it. We have other cars that aren ’ t haunted with memories so searing they ’ ll melt the flesh off your hands when you grip the steering wheel. 
 
 The van hummed happily when I turned the key in the ignition, as if it were glad to be of use again, after all this time. The heat kicked on, but I knew it would be awhile before I could actually feel anything. Why didn ’ t I bring gloves out with me? I blew on my hands and rubbed them together to create some warmth. Better than nothing. 
 
 I couldn ’ t avoid it any longer. 
 
 The passenger seat stared me right in the face. “ I can ’ t do this, ” I said aloud. But I didn ’ t move. Something inside me knew that I had to face this: for myself, for Will. 
 The stereo gave me sanctuary, filled the van with the sounds of Dad ’ s favorite CD, a compilation of Debussy that we ’ d gotten him for Christmas two years back. I closed my eyes and tilted my head back. 
 
 God... I hadn ’ t heard these songs, seen these images in so long. Anything associated with the van, associated with that night, wasn ’ t allowed to enter my brain. Until now. Seven months of painful solitude. But now, I felt relaxed... a cathartic release... eyes closing… 
 
 Eyes snapped open. The sky was dark and milky, full of stars. And it was freezing! The van was off, but I hadn ’ t turned the key back. 
 
 “ Fuck, the battery died. ” 
 
 Still, I didn ’ t want to go inside. I could see my sister and my parents in the living room, lights dim, sitting on the couch watching television. They looked so joyful, laughing and smiling. How can they be so happy? Especially around the holidays, with Will gone? 
 
 My gaze dropped to the passenger seat again. *Might as well. I searched through my jacket pocket and pulled out a tiny bowl and a ziplock bag with a little bit of weed in it. Packed the bowl and grabbed my lighter. This one ’ s for you, buddy. I hope you ’ re happy, wherever you are. * 
 
 The first hit felt so good, like a cloud of joy that took all of my pain away. *Man, I don ’ t get it. Why ’ d you have to go? We were so tight. I know life was hard for you, with your Dad passing away. But you still had your mom. And you had us, my family. * 
 
 With no one to pass to, I took my second hit. *We loved you so much. Everything would ’ ve worked out. We could ’ ve gotten you a better therapist. Gone to more shows, I know how much you loved going to the city for shows. Life was so beautiful, and you were so young…* 
 
 There was no point in taking a third hit. My hands began to shake again, this time not from the cold, but from panic. My chest felt tight, struggled to breathe. Hot tears careened down my cheeks. 
 
 “ I loved you, Will! ” I screamed. “ We all loved you, you asshole! Why wasn ’ t that enough? Why couldn ’ t our love save you? ”

LLM_2:
The van where Will died loitered in my mind like an unwelcome guest, its rusty door cREAKING open with an unsettling familiarity.

Snow crunched beneath my steps, a brittle crunch that seemed almost deliberate – as if the very earth itself was trying to tell me something, or perhaps it was just the cold, unforgiving wind that whispered secrets in the darkness. Flakes clung together on their fragile edges like tiny icicle shards, each one etching a secret story in their delicate curves. I tramped through them with a steady beat, one I knew for seven long, sorrowful months.

It was early December, that fleeting moment when the first flakes fell softly, like tears, trying not to intrudes on the sorrow that hung like heavy fog in every corner. Seven cold weeks since Will slipped into eternal silence – an act of desperation that shattered us all, leaving behind a trail of shattered dreams and fractured hearts. And seven months since his vacant eyes stared into mine for the last time – the final look he ever gave, which still lingered like the ghost of a summer breeze.

His life slipped away like sand between fingers – fragile and tenuous, snapped without warning, taking with it a piece of our collective soul. Yet, even in death, Will left behind memories that refused to fade, haunting me still. Memories of speeding down deserted streets in that cursed van, his lifeless body slumped against the door, as the world outside grew darker, colder, with each passing moment.

A small breeze caresses us once more – its gentle touch dancing across his pale face like snowflakes on a winter's night, dissolves silently upon impact, erasing all evidence of its presence. But the neighborhood remains still, save for Nadia's dog, who barks loudly after spotting something two doors down – perhaps just a squirrel, unaware of my pain.

Midday sun beats down upon us, casting long shadows across the empty streets – everyone lost in a world of their own, oblivious to my despair. My hands tremble violently now, not just from the chill that seeps into my bones, nor from fear of what I'm about to face – but from a deep-seated dread that refuses to subside.

With a shaking hand, insert the key into the lock and twist it hard – familiar yet uneasy, this sound that echoes through my memories like whispers in an empty church. Three pulls later, it finally opens up – ceding me to a van that stands motionlessly, haunted by memories of Will, where his presence still lingers, refusing to leave.

No one else will drive these wheels – not mom or dad, neither Nad – for they have other cars left that don't carry the weight of such memories. Those that haunt me with every turn of this wheel, stripping me of skin, flesh, soul, until I feel nothing but a hollow shell of myself.

Yet, when I turn the keys, once again the van comes to life – engine humming smoothly, happiness palpating through the air – like it's trying, yet again, tell a story of hope, of life. Heat kicks in afterwards – warm air dancing through me, attempting to chase away the lingering chill.

Why didn I bring gloves outside, on this winter night? The wind bites into palms, sharp as knives – I blow warm breath over my skin and rub my hands tight, searching for warmth where none seems to be. It's better than nothing – and, for now – it will have to suffice.

But I can't put things behind myself any longer. Not the pain, guilt, regret – nor the memories, eternally imprinted in this mind of mine. They stare straight ahead – passenger seat, gloomy expression – saying everything in silence. As I speak aloud – "Can't do it" – still not moving. For something deep within me knows that time has arrived – time to call forth new resolve, new hope.

And so, in comes the stereo – taking center stage – Dad's favorite CD, flooding the car with his favorite melodies – Deb's gift, two years ago – lost and forgotten in night of grief. Now, perhaps, they could be allowed back into this haunted mind – where memories have died – refused entry.

Seven solitary, painful months are past – this release feels cathartic – letting out a long breath – eyes closed – just for a moment. Eyes snap open – sky above, dark and starry – van turned dead, flat battery, completely.

"Fucking dead," I mutter – frustration, despair, anger – all entwined in one anguished cry. Time to start again – from scratch, maybe – to find meaning in these endless, hollow days – or maybe, just maybe I'll find a way to bring Will back – if only in memories – memories I still can cherish. In the end, all I know is I have this – me – alone – with only memories left to carry me through. Tonight, though – tonight, there's no driving – only darkness – complete and utter darkness that envelops me like shroud. Maybe tomorrow – maybe tomorrow I will find my way – find Will – in me. Or maybe not – who knows?

The paper addresses the task of dealing with named entities in goal oriented dialog systems. Named entities, and rare words in general, are indeed troublesome since adding them to the dictionary is expensive, replacing them with coarse labels (ne_loc, unk) looses information, and so on. The proposed solution is to extend neural dialog models by introducing a named entity table, instantiated on the fly, where the keys are distributed representations of the dialog context and the values are the named entities themselves. The approach is applied to settings involving interacting to a database and a mechanism for handling the interaction is proposed. The resulting model is illustrated on a few goal-oriented dialog tasks.


I found the paper difficult to read. The concrete mappings used to create the NE keys and attention keys are missing. Providing more structure to the text would also be useful vs. long, wordy paragraphs. Here are some specific questions:

1. How are the keys generated? That are the functions used? Does the "knowledge of the current user utterance" include the word itself? The authors should include the exact model specification, including for the HRED model.

2. According to the description, referring to an existing named entity must be done by "generating a key to match the keys in the NE table and then retrieve the corresponding value and use it". Is there a guarantee that a same named entity, appearing later in the dialog, will be given the same key?  Or are the keys for already found entities retrieved directly, by value?

3. In the decoding phase, how does the system decide whether to query the DB?

4. How is the model trained?

In its current form, it's not clear how the proposed approach tackles the shortcomings mentioned in the introduction. Furthermore, while the highlighted contribution is the named entity table, it is always used in conjunction to the database approach. This raises the question whether the named entity table can only work in this context.

For the structured QA task, there are 400 training examples, and 100 named entities. This means that the number of training examples per named entity is very small. Is that correct? If yes, then it's not very surprising that adding the named entities to the vocabulary leads to overfitting. Have you compared with using random embeddings for the named entities?

Typos: page 2, second-to-last paragraph: firs -> first, page 7, second to last paragraph: and and -> and
LLM_1:
The paper addresses the task of dealing with named entities in goal-oriented dialog systems, a critical area of research that has significant implications for enhancing user interaction and information retrieval. Named entities, such as specific locations, organizations, and individuals, along with rare words, pose considerable challenges in natural language processing. The difficulties arise from the high costs associated with adding these entities to the dictionary, which can involve extensive manual curation and validation processes. Furthermore, when entities are replaced with coarse labels such as "ne_loc" or "unk," valuable contextual information is often lost, leading to reduced accuracy and user satisfaction in dialog systems. 

The proposed solution aims to extend neural dialog models by introducing a named entity table that is instantiated dynamically during the conversation. In this innovative approach, the keys of the table are generated as distributed representations derived from the dialog context, while the values correspond to the named entities themselves. This method allows for a more flexible handling of named entities, as it enables the system to adapt to the ongoing conversation in real time. The authors present a mechanism for interacting with a database, which is essential for retrieving relevant information based on user queries. The resulting model is illustrated through several goal-oriented dialog tasks, showcasing its effectiveness and adaptability in various scenarios.

However, I found the paper difficult to read, partly due to the lack of concrete mappings that clarify how the NE keys and attention keys are generated. It would be beneficial for the authors to provide a more structured presentation of their methodology, as the current long, wordy paragraphs can hinder comprehension. Here are some specific questions that could help clarify the approach:

1. How are the keys generated? What specific functions are employed in this process? Additionally, does the "knowledge of the current user utterance" encompass the actual words spoken, or is it limited to contextual cues? The authors should include a detailed model specification, particularly for the Hierarchical Recurrent Encoder-Decoder (HRED) model, to ensure replicability and understanding of their methodology.

2. The description suggests that referring to an existing named entity requires "generating a key to match the keys in the NE table and then retrieving the corresponding value." Is there a guarantee that a named entity encountered later in the dialog will receive the same key, or are the keys for previously identified entities retrieved directly by their values? This aspect is crucial for maintaining consistency and coherence throughout the dialog.

3. In the decoding phase, what criteria does the system use to decide whether to query the database? Understanding the decision-making process in this context is essential for evaluating the efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed model.

4. How is the model trained? A comprehensive overview of the training process would provide valuable insight into how the authors ensure that the model learns effectively from the available data.

In its current form, it remains unclear how the proposed approach addresses the shortcomings highlighted in the introduction. Furthermore, while the primary contribution of the paper is the named entity table, it consistently operates in conjunction with the database approach. This raises an important question: can the named entity table function independently of the database context, or is its utility inherently tied to it?

For the structured QA task, the authors note that there are 400 training examples and 100 named entities. This distribution implies that the number of training examples available for each named entity is quite limited, resulting in an average of only four examples per entity. If this understanding is correct, it is not surprising that the addition of named entities to the vocabulary could lead to overfitting, as the model may struggle to generalize effectively from such a small sample size. Have the authors considered comparing their approach with the use of random embeddings for the named entities to evaluate the impact on model performance?

Lastly, I would like to point out a couple of typographical errors: on page 2, the second-to-last paragraph contains "firs" instead of "first," and on page 7, the second-to-last paragraph features a repetition with "and and." Addressing these minor issues will enhance the overall presentation of the paper.

Overall, I believe this work is a nice complement to the instance-dependent sample complexity of zeroth-order optimization. The presentation is good with clear upper and lower bounds. My main concerns are summarized as below.

1. I'm confused about the gap in the dependence of dimension $d$ in the upper and lower bounds. Theorem 3 suggests that the constant $c$ in lower bound is $c'(1-Lip(f)/L)^d$, and claims that the results are direct corollary of Theorem 2 and Proposition 1. However, in theorem 2 the constant $c$ has a extra dependence of $2^{-7d}$, which can be huge when the dimension is large and suggests another mismatch of order $2^{-d}$ in the upper and lower bounds. Is there any other technique applied to mitigate this factor in the lower bound? Otherwise, the authors shall state this gap clearly in the introduction and theorem instead of hiding it in the constant $c'$.

2. Based on the dependence of smoothness in the lower bound in Theorem 2, the adaptivity to all range of smoothness seems to be a natural and important question towards fully instance-dependent optimal bound. It is mentioned in line 89 that 'our lower bound suggests that no adaptivity could be possible for certified algorithm'. This is not clear from Proposition 2 and 3, since Proposition 2 seems to suggest that there exists algorithm that can achieve constant sample size when $f$ is exactly $L$-Lipschitz. Could the author elaborate on this point?

3. The mismatch between one dimension and high dimension is quite interesting. In Proposition 3, the authors suggest that in one dimension, the term $S_c$ is again a valid lower bound. Does this mean that the problem when we know exactly the smoothness of the function in one dimension can be harder than that in high dimension? Does this also imply that there exists algorithm that is adaptive to smoothness in one dimension? It would be great if some intuitive explanation can be added on why the discrepancy between one dimension and high dimension happens.

Besides the concerns mentioned above, I think understanding exactly the instance-dependent optimal zeroth-order optimization is a good contribution. I'm happy to adjust the points accordingly if my questions are resolved.

***Update based on the author response:
The authors have resolved most of the questions listed above. Although the exponential gap in dimension is still tricky, I acknowledge that this is an open problem left and this work makes a first step towards understanding the instance-dependent optimal zeroth-order optimization in high dimension. I have adjusted my score accordingly.

Overall, I find this work to be a valuable complement to the literature on instance-dependent sample complexity in zeroth-order optimization. The presentation is well-structured, with clear derivations of both upper and lower bounds, making the theoretical contributions accessible. However, several technical points warrant further clarification to strengthen the manuscript’s rigor and transparency. My primary concerns are detailed below.

1. **Gap in Dimension Dependence Between Upper and Lower Bounds**:  
   I remain puzzled by the discrepancy in the dimension \(d\) dependence between the upper and lower bounds. Theorem 3 states that the constant \(c\) in the lower bound takes the form \(c'(1 -  ext{Lip}(f)/L)^d\), and it is presented as a direct corollary of Theorem 2 and Proposition 1. However, Theorem 2 itself introduces an additional factor of \(2^{-7d}\) in the constant \(c\), which becomes exponentially large in high dimensions and suggests a potential mismatch on the order of \(2^{-d}\) between the bounds. This raises a methodological question: Are there any specialized techniques, such as dimension reduction or concentration arguments, that mitigate this factor in the lower bound derivation? If not, for full transparency, the authors should explicitly acknowledge this exponential gap in the introduction and Theorem 3, rather than embedding it within the constant \(c'\). Clarifying this would help readers better assess the tightness of the results in high-dimensional settings.

2. **Adaptivity to Smoothness and Certified Algorithms**:  
   The lower bound in Theorem 2 depends critically on the smoothness parameters, making adaptivity across the full range of smoothness a natural and important direction for achieving fully instance-dependent optimal bounds. In line 89, the authors claim that “our lower bound suggests that no adaptivity could be possible for certified algorithms,” but this conclusion is not immediately evident from Propositions 2 and 3. Specifically, Proposition 2 seems to indicate that an algorithm can achieve a constant sample size when \(f\) is exactly \(L\)-Lipschitz, which appears to contradict the non-adaptivity claim. Could the authors elaborate on how the lower bound rules out adaptivity for certified algorithms, perhaps by discussing the interplay between Proposition 2’s algorithmic result and the lower bound’s assumptions? A more detailed explanation would bridge this conceptual gap and reinforce the manuscript’s narrative on fundamental limitations.

3. **Discrepancy Between One-Dimensional and High-Dimensional Cases**:  
   The contrast between the one-dimensional and high-dimensional settings is particularly intriguing. Proposition 3 asserts that in one dimension, the term \(S_c\) remains a valid lower bound. This prompts two deeper questions: First, does this imply that the problem of optimizing a function with known smoothness is inherently harder in one dimension than in higher dimensions? Second, does it suggest the existence of algorithms that are adaptive to smoothness specifically in one dimension? Adding intuitive explanations—for instance, discussing the role of geometric constraints, search space structure, or the behavior of zeroth-order queries in low versus high dimensions—would illuminate why this dimensional discrepancy arises and enhance the conceptual takeaways for the reader.

Beyond these points, I believe that rigorously characterizing instance-dependent optimal rates for zeroth-order optimization is a meaningful contribution, and I appreciate the authors’ efforts to advance this line of inquiry. I am open to revising my evaluation should these concerns be adequately addressed.

***Update based on the author response:**  
The authors have thoughtfully addressed most of the questions raised above. While the exponential dimension gap remains a challenging open problem, I recognize that this work represents an important initial step toward understanding instance-dependent optimal zeroth-order optimization in high dimensions. Accordingly, I have updated my assessment to reflect this progress.

The single, "A Moment Like This," catapulted to the top of the charts, going on to break a 38-year-old record previously held by The Beatles for the biggest leap to number one on the Billboard Hot 100—a remarkable feat that underscored the show's immediate cultural impact. # A Pop-Culture Phenomenon Is Born: How *American Idol*’s First Season Launched a Superstar and Set Records

In a move that would become a signature moment for the franchise, Kelly Clarkson delivered the coronation song during the finale of *American Idol*’s debut season and released the single right after the season wrapped. Titled “A Moment Like This,” the track rocketed to No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100, shattering a 38-year chart record previously held by The Beatles for the largest leap to the top spot. The staggering achievement highlighted the show’s instant and powerful grip on popular culture.

Meanwhile, runner-up Justin Guarini opted not to release a song immediately after the finale—making him the only first-season finalist to pass up the opportunity—a choice that may have slowed his early career momentum.

The two would later join forces for the 2003 musical film *From Justin to Kelly*, which was met with harsh reviews from critics who dismissed its weak storyline and uninspired production. The movie became an infamous blip in both of their professional journeys.

Nevertheless, Clarkson quickly moved past that stumble. She has since risen to become the most internationally successful *American Idol* alum, with global album sales surpassing 23 million, multiple Grammy Awards, and a versatile influence spanning pop, country, and beyond. Today, she stands as a bona fide global music icon.
